PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania: VHF, UHF Transmission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
That the mountainous terrain and geography of Tasmania makes VHF television transmissions the most suitable for the State;
That more than 30,000 Tasmanians will have to purchase new television receivers and new antennae if commercial television in the State is forced to change from VHF to the UHF band;

Your petitioners therefore request that the requirement by the Department of Transport and Communications to force Tasmania's two commercial television stations to change from the VHF to the UHF band by 1993 be immediately rescinded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Environmental Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled:
The humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is urgent need for the United Nations to adopt an Environmental Bill of Rights using the 1987 Report by the World Commission on Environment and Development.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament pass an `Environmental Bill of Rights', therefore giving Australia a leading role in environmental protection.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate. We, the undersigned medical students of Australia, oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. We believe:-
There should not be two tiers of medical insurance rebates for General Practice.
Undergraduate training in general practice should be upgraded, and continuing medical education should be an independent activity controlled by the profession.
The mechanism for establishing the vocational register proposed in the Act is unacceptable.
Vocational training for General Practice should be structured so that appropriate skills can be acquired in a reasonable and not an excessive time.
The present and proposed Medicare rebates for general practitioner services are inadequate.
Therefore we humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will support the medical profession to achieve these resolutions.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate assembled:

We, the undersigned medical students and medical practitioners of Australia, oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. We believe:

All Australians should have equal access to our health care system and that there should not be two tiers of medical insurance rebates for general practice and we reject the concept of a vocational register for general practitioners.
Undergraduate training in general practice should be upgraded and that ongoing medical education should continue to be controlled independently by the profession.

The mechanism for establishing the vocational register proposed in the legislation violates the ethics of the medical profession as embodied in the Declaration of Geneva, and is totally unacceptable. (See Medical Ethics on the reverse side.)

We pray that the proposed changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 should be rejected outright by the Senate and that it should be replaced with a broadly based consultative process to address the problems within general medical practice and general practice training.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH (PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS DETERMINATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: A bill for an Act to amend the National Health Act 1953 to revoke a determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and to provide for proper parliamentary control of future determinations.
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purposes of this Bill are two:
1. To disallow the determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal so that it shall have no force or effect and
2. To provide that in future such determinations are disallowable instruments.

The present determination, if implemented, will be a severe penalty to pharmacists. It will cause 20 per cent plus real reduction in PBS income. This is in addition to the 12 per cent real reduction in income suffered by pharmacists over the last twelve months.

It appears the Government has cast about for areas of reduction in expenditure on health and has settled on the poor hapless pharmacists. This, at a time when pharmacists have already been squeezed as a result of Federal Government moves.

The result of this determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal is that many pharmacists will just close their doors. Unfortunately, many closing will be those providing the most needed services such as those in small towns or isolated suburban areas. Those that receive specific assistance in these circumstances will be and remain precariously dependent on this and may yet decide not to continue in a country pharmacy.

Those pharmacies which survive will do so by cutting costs. The only way they can do that is to reduce staff. That will result in a drastic cut in service to the public and the lowering of standards of pharmacy practice in Australia.
Pharmacists who have recently graduated are already finding difficulty obtaining employment. Some sackings have already occurred.

The tribunal acknowledged that pharmacies would be placed in jeopardy but did not consider the wider costs to the community of pharmacy closures. They did not consider the increase in transport costs to the consumer who would have to travel further to have his prescriptions dispensed. Thus the total cost to the community may rise even while Government expenditure falls. Unfortunately, this Government rarely does total social costing.

It is a matter of concern that the costs of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme are ``blowing out'' with an anticipated increase from $1000m to $1200m in just one year. But this piecemeal approach of taking $92m over two years from the pockets of pharmacists is not good enough. A complete review of the PBS is required, and I duly moved a motion to that effect last September in the Senate.
It is evident that the Tribunal's decisions have been based on flawed information. It is a matter of concern that no-one on the Tribunal had specific knowledge of the pharmaceutical profession.

This Bill includes provisions such that further determinations will be subject to disallowance by Parliament. Had these determinations been in the form of regulations I could have simply moved for disallowance rather than introduce a private member's Bill. If the Government sets up a Tribunal and sets the terms of reference, it is only appropriate that Parliament be able to disallow the determinations.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935 to remove sales tax on certain paper made from recycled pulp.
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Many continue to argue that `education' should be the principal instrument for social behaviour modification in the area of resource exploitation and conservation. As long ago as 1968, Garrett Hardin, an eminent American biologist, published in the journal, Science, a seminal essay titled `The Tragedy of the Commons'. Hardin convincingly argued that attempting to bring about such change through ``education'' was counterproductive. What is meant by education in this context is conscience development or conscience sensitisation. Those who have a conscience or whose conscience can be activated by `education' are stimulated to act `responsibly'. Others continue to behave in the same old way. What Hardin showed was that those who acted on conscience were put at a disadvantage.

For example, in the use of recycled paper, those who presently use recycled paper believing, correctly, that to do so is environmentally more responsible, put themselves at a disadvantage. Paper made from recycled pulp is generally more expensive, it is not available from all suppliers. And so it is in so many areas of social or environmental responsibility. Relying on conscience or `education' to get the job done is counter productive because it puts those with a conscience at a disadvantage. Those with a conscience dwindle in numbers while those without proliferate and prosper. Hardin demonstrated that to change behaviour one must also change the milieu in which people operate to one in which conscience and good behaviour are rewarded, not penalised. If `conscience' works with, rather than against, the prevailing system of rewards and penalties, then behaviour will change and the new behaviour will spread through the community.

In a society whose structure and direction are predicated so heavily on economic considerations it is both appropriate and consistent to use price incentives and cost penalties to achieve desirable change.

There are already a small number in Australia who use recycled paper. The CSIRO report, Pulp Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection looked at the relative price of bleached and less bleached paper and said, `The increasing orientation to lesser bleached products in some countries, will affect at most, only marginally these development opportunities'. Given the relative prices this conclusion may be justified. But price relativities can be changed and should be changed to reflect environmental as well as production costs. This is appropriately done by Government by way of tax as the unfettered market has no suitable alternative mechanism for translating environmental damage into a price penalty. The Government `corrects' the market so that the consumer pays the full cost of production including resource depletion and environmental pollution.

At present both new paper and recycled paper-paper made from recycled pulp-attract a 20 per cent sales tax. The price of new paper made from native forests does not adequately reflect the cost of destruction of this natural resource. The value of such forests extends well beyond their value as a source of either wood chips for paper or sawn timber. This value is not adequately reflected in the price paid for the timber and chips taken from such forests. If it were, the rate of regeneration of native forests would equal or exceed the rate of exploitation. This is not the case. If Government were to see sales tax, not merely as a way of raising revenue, but as a way of fully imposing on the market, `the user pays', then sales tax on new paper would be substantially increased.

This bill proposes an alternative, and hopefully more acceptable way of shifting the consumption of paper significantly toward paper made from recycled pulp. The removal of the 20 per cent sales tax from recycled paper will bring its price into line with or below that of new paper. Those who, out of concern for the impact of paper demand on the environment, choose to buy recycled paper will not suffer a price penalty but rather be rewarded with a cheaper product. Those, without an environmental conscience may continue to consume new paper and suffer a slight penalty or may choose to use recycled paper on price alone.

When the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classification) Amendment Bill (No. 2) was being debated in June I attempted unsuccessfully to move an amendment to remove the 20 per cent sales tax from recycled paper. This amendment was defeated by the combined vote of Government and Opposition members. Within weeks the Opposition was promising to remove the 20 per cent sales tax from recycled paper and the Prime Minister promised the same in his environment statement of July 20. Many people now wrongly believe the sales tax has already been removed.

I have given consideration to legislating a sliding scale of sales tax depending on the content of new and recycled fibre. This has been rejected in favour of a more easily administered single content of 80 per cent by weight above which sales tax shall not be payable. The 80 per cent level will allow a range of papers to be made by suitable admixture of new fibre. Attention will need to be given to provision within the regulations for correct certification as to the fibre content of paper and for suitable penalties for incorrect or misleading certification.

At present some 30 to 40 per cent of paper is recycled in Australia but except for a very small amount this is used to manufacture cardboard and other packaging, then to be burnt or otherwise discarded. Thus, at best, 30 to 40 per cent of fibre is now used twice. By recycling fibre from paper into paper before turning it to cardboard and packaging, fibre will be used more times before eventually being discarded. In this way the demand on forests for new fibre can be substantially reduced.

The Prime Minister has claimed that Australia leads the world in environmental protection. This is not true. We took ten years longer than the US, Canada, Norway and Sweden to ban CFCs in pressure packs and the course of the Australian natural environment is still down hill. The Prime Minister's July 20 Environment Statement contained no initiative on greenhouse. The Government seems to assume that environmental leadership will necessarily involve economic penalty. The reverse is the case. As the world recognises the need for greater environmental care those countries which lead with the new technology and the accompanying and necessary new institutional and social arrangements will have an economic as well as a responsibility lead on other nations.

So far the Government has made no move to give effect to the Prime Minister's promise. This Bill gives both Government and Opposition a chance to redeem their promises. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1989ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Committee suspended its consideration of the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill last night I had responded to some criticisms which had been made. I am sorry that my colleague Senator Coulter is not in the chamber at this stage. I hope that he will be here.
—He has been here; he has just--

—I thank the Minister. There were three points raised to which I think some response is necessary. Firstly, Senator Coulter said that since we have said that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) is to be abolished should the Government succeed with its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) proposal and since what is proposed here is only an interim arrangement, why is the Opposition so concerned about the rules governing ministerial directions in relation to the corporate plan, which is what this amendment is about.

SPEECH.PARA: The response to that is that we on this side of the chamber do not know when the ATSIC proposal will come into effect. Had we accepted what the Government said at the end of 1987 it would have come into effect shortly afterwards. We are now almost two years down the track and, as far as we are concerned, ATSIC still remains subject to the passage of its legislation through this place. Presumably, it will receive further consideration in another place and will then come back to this chamber. Presumably, it will then receive royal assent and be proclaimed. I suggest to my colleague that it is proper for us to assume that the process is somewhere in the future and that it is necessary that the Bill before us be put into as good a form as possible. While he may be correct, it does not follow that the Bill will not operate for some considerable time. On that argument we think that it is worthwhile getting the Bill right.

Secondly, Senator Coulter made what I thought was a proper criticism. He took up my words that we must look at the words of the Bill. He has looked at the words of the amendment. What I thought he was saying was that he would rather have seen our amendment couched to say, `The Commission is not required to comply with any general direction given by the Minister'. Had it been in that form his riposte to us would have been possible. If that is so I may seek leave to amend the amendment to add the word `general', because I think that his point warrants some response.

We wish to press the amendment because we cannot accept that it is not necessary. The Minister has read from section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. But on that section 11, which concerns directions by the Minister in relation to the Aboriginal Development Commission, I repeat what I said last night. Subsection (1) says that the Minister can issue directions; sub- section (2) limits the Minister, but not in relation to the corporate plan. I know the Minister said last night that there was some question as to whether subsection (2) would apply to the corporate plan. I have to say to him that on our reading we do not think it does. We think the corporate plan is separate.

When we go to the only ministerial direction that has ever been issued, we see that it was a cause celebre which came before the Senate Select Committee of which Senator Coulter and I were members. It related to the Aboriginal Development Commission and was the immediate cause of the dismissal of eight commissioners in 1988.

For those reasons I say again that we believe that it is necessary to add amendment No. 2, as circulated. That amendment would insert a new subclause (4) into proposed section 10a in the terms in which it has been circulated to make it quite clear that the Commission is required to prepare a corporate plan but that the Minister cannot determine what that corporate plan will be. That is what the amendment we have circulated moves. Having said all that and in light of Senator Coulter's quite correct point last night, I seek leave of the Committee to insert the word `general' into our proposed amendment, so that it would now read:
Page 2, clause 5, after proposed subsection 10a (3), add the following new subsection:
``(4) The Commission is not required to comply with any general direction given by the Minister about the contents of the corporate plan.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the Opposition amendment as has now been put before the chamber, by leave. I simply indicate that the reason for the Government's resistance to the amendment has been the inference that lies behind it that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs would be minded to dictate to the Commission the contents of its corporate plan. Quite clearly, the whole structure of section 10a as proposed by clause 5 makes it clear that the Commission is to bear the full responsibility. It is mandatory that it prepare the corporate plan. The obligation falls squarely on the Commission, in consultation with the Minister. It is consultation rather than direction which is the hallmark of the preparation of the plan.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of honourable senators to section 11 (2) of the principal Act. Last night I said that it may be arguable, but I did not press the argument, that a corporate plan could fall within the terms of subsection (2), but I finally said that by analogy and by looking at the directions actually contained in the general directions issued on 11 April 1989 one gets a clear indication of the way in which the Minister intends to operate so as to make the Commission aware of suggestions as to the corporate plan, but not making directions which are binding on the Commission. That combination of the ethos of section 11 (2), section 10a as proposed, and the actual evidence we have of the directions already issued by the Minister under section 11, led me to characterise the moving of this amendment by the Opposition as somewhat overwrought, somewhat overly nervous as to what might be done by the Minister. I say `the' Minister, because the argument has become somewhat personalised.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is any Minister.

—I concede that in drafting legislation one has to deal with any Minister who might have those responsibilities in the future. Rather than take up a great deal of time of the Senate on this clause, and whilst reiterating that the Government does not see the need for this clause which has been moved by the Opposition and indicating my unhappiness with it, I indicate that we certainly will not vote against it in a way which leads to a division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not seek to delay the Senate if the Government has indicated that it is prepared to accept the Opposition's amendment. Senator Peter Baume's argument that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs had in the past given a direction which had had rather catastrophic consequences-a conclusion with which I totally agree-is not quite relevant to this case because the amendment Senator Baume seeks to insert is a general direction specifically with respect to the corporate plan, and the direction which was given was not with respect to a corporate plan. I will not seek to prolong the debate any further.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 4, clause 12, proposed subsection 32a (1), line 34, leave out ``by the Minister after consulting the Commission'', insert ``by the Commission after consulting the Minister''.
(4) Page 5, clause 12, proposed section 32c, line 18, leave out ``Minister'', insert ``Commission''.
(5) Page 5, clause 12, proposed subsection 32d (1), line 22, leave out ``Minister'' insert ``Commission''.
(6) Page 6, clause 12, proposed subsection 32e (1), line 2, leave out ``Minister'' insert ``Commission''.
(7) Page 6, clause 12, proposed section 32f, line 12, leave out ``Minister'' insert ``Commission''.
(8) Page 6, clause 12, proposed subsection 32g (1), line 14, leave out ``Minister may, after consulting the Commission'', insert ``Commission may, after consulting the Minister''.
(9) Page 6, clause 12, proposed subsection 32g (2), line 27, leave out ``Minister'' insert ``Commission''.
(10) Page 6, clause 12, proposed section 32h, line 31, leave out ``Minister'' insert ``Commission''.

I move these amendments together in a spirit of trying to avoid prolonged debate on each individual amendment. The amendments are under the heading `General Manager'. We move them together because they all have a common purpose and single argument can cover what we are concerned about and what we are trying to achieve. The amendments all relate to clause 12, and in each instance we seek to leave out `by the Minister after consulting the Commission' and insert the words the other way around-`by the Commission after consulting the Minister'.

The Opposition has listened to and read the statements of Ministers over some years-including those of the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who has had the carriage of this legislation-about the desirability of Aboriginal self-management and, in the Minister's terms, the desirability of self-determination. We have said, `Let us look at the legislation which is promoted by the Government to see how those ideals are put into effect'. It seems to us that the clause as drafted is inconsistent with either the ideal of self-management or the ideal of self-determination. These are the words being used by the Government to describe its approach within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission package of Bills. What is in clauses 12 and 13 of this Bill is the very reverse.

The provision reflects a determination by Government to control the staffing of the Aboriginal Development Commission and it is manifested in this instance by a determination that the Minister should appoint the General Manager. Let us just look at that for a moment. If the Aboriginal Development Commission is operating as a statutory commission under its own statute with its own duties and functions and under its own corporate plan, are we really going to say, if we believe in self-management by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, that we will not even let it appoint its own General Manager? Of course it should appoint its General Manager. I understand that another statutory body might take a different approach. We might say in relation to a statutory authority like the Pipeline Authority that a different situation applies. But this legislation is Aboriginal legislation. It is not just a statute as written. This legislation is required to reflect an expression of ideology, an expression of values, an expression of priorities by the Government.

The Government has told us day after day about the desire to see self-management promoted. The ADC has been, and remains at the moment, the flagship of Aboriginal self-management. Since 1980, when the Aboriginal Development Commission was first created, the Commission itself has appointed its General Manager. We are not asking for something new. We are asking that a situation which has always applied to the ADC continue to apply. The Government proposes in clause 12 that that situation should change; that the ADC which has appointed its own General Manager should no longer be able so to do. The Opposition says that it simply cannot understand this. The Government appoints the commissioners. We do not all agree with some of the choices the Government made last year. But it is proper that the Government appoint the commissioners. Surely the commissioners can then appoint their General Manager. Each of amendments 3 to 10 inclusive, that we have moved, as Senator Coulter said, serve to reverse what the Government proposes-to maintain the status quo ante but to maintain it in the name of Aboriginal self-management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume has eloquently expressed the philosophy which I believe should underlie these particular clauses. The Australian Democrats will accept those changes because they reverse the role and preserve an adequate input from the Minister. It is appropriate that several of the things mentioned should be after consultation with the Minister. But clearly the Commission is the body that should have the primary decision making function. We accept the primacy of that role and we accept also that it gives effect to what the Government has stated in its intention: namely, to give greater facility for Aboriginal self-management and self-determination. Therefore we will support the amendment moved by the Opposition.

—I am very grateful that Senator Coulter, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, is agreeing to the Opposition's amendment. It is quite clear that the role of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) would be reduced only to a puppet role if it could not appoint its own General Manager. We have talked long an hard about self-determination and self-management. We have seen self-management evolve in some of the communities where the Aboriginal people are looking after their own interests. More and more white advisers are being removed from the communities or are voluntary removing themselves as the Aboriginal people are coming to the point where they are looking after their own communities. A lot of self-management and self-determination has evolved in the last five or six years at the grassroots level and at the coal face. For the Government to put forward this proposition that the ADC cannot appoint its own General Manager is a big march backwards in time. I am very happy to say that we will be able to go out into the Aboriginal communities and say we have won the right for the ADC to be self-sufficient and to have the right to appoint its own staff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept this amendment. Whilst it is true that self-management is a major principle underlying the reconstruction of Aboriginal affairs attendant upon the various events of the last couple of years, it is equally true that there is a need to ensure accountability, particularly to the Parliament. It is considered by the Government that the way in which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs might be able to take responsibility for the appointment-and, of course, the termination of appointment-of the General Manager and the manner in which he discharges his duties allows the Parliament to ensure that the responsibility of the Minister for the running of the Aboriginal Development Commission is able to be enforced in terms of the responsibility of a Minister to the various chambers of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is really the question of accountability to the Parliament which lies behind this proposition in a general policy sense. Attached to that, though, is the fact that the General Manager is vested with the powers of the Secretary of a department. In that respect I understand that it is extremely unusual for a person vested with such powers not to be appointed by the Government. That is one of the reasons why the appointment of the General Manager of the Commission by the Minister was thought to be appropriate. In fact, the General Manager will be exercising all those powers vested in him as equivalent to the Secretary of a major department of state. Clause 13, proposed section 33 (2) of the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill, reads:

The General Manager has all the powers of, or exercisable by, a secretary under the Public Service Act 1922, so far as those powers relate to the branch of the Australian Public Service comprising the staff referred to in subsection (1) . . .

That was one of the reasons which encouraged the Government to think it sensible that the Minister appoint the General Manager. The overall consideration was responsibility: to allow the Minister to take responsibility for the appointment of such a crucial person and for him to be held responsible by this Parliament in the ways we have become accustomed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during the second reading debate on the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill I was critical of a number of actions of the commissioners of the ADC in July 1988 when they chose to change the status of Mr Mick O'Brien. Mr O'Brien had been a long serving General Manager of the ADC. As many honourable senators will be aware from previous annual reports of the ADC to the Parliament, Mr O'Brien played a very significant role and discharged his functions as General Manager of the Commission properly. As a result of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, stacking the Board of the Commission in May 1988 with a group of commissioners that were obviously put in place to do only his bidding, a point of conflict was created concerning the General Manager's position. Honourable senators will be aware that last week Senator Teague incorporated in his speech a certain amount of evidence from the transcript of a discussion between the commissioners. Let me reflect, again, on a couple of those points. I will quote directly from the commissioners:

SPEECH.PARA: Stand Mick-
that is, Mr O'Brien-
aside and say that the Chief officer of the ADC is now Mike Stewart and all staff answerable to him. That's it.
Further on the commissioners say:

We should knock this into a resolution. Mike Stewart is now the position of the General Manager. Put Mick O'Brien on special duties, and if he can't come at those, we can put him aside. Mike Stewart will hone in on them and Shirley is not to leave Canberra.
They go on:

The other thing is we want to cover the political scandal. We don't want Mike Stewart getting involved with all the administrative matters. We've got to be careful about that. If we give him all O'Brien's delegations, he's going to be tied into knots. They'll make it hard for him. They'll just try and knock him off. What we want is a politician.

It might appear that there is a double-edged sword in dealing with this amendment. We have what I would say are very openly criticisable actions of the commissioners, who were seeking to make changes. What I argued yesterday was that those actions were motivated by political reasons by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) using the Hand-picked, specially appointed commissioners to achieve a change. This was different to the satisfactory arrangements where the Commission had developed a proper, an appropriate and a professional system with regard to the General Manager's position.

I reinforce the points made by Senator Peter Baume that Aboriginal people themselves must be allowed to take the responsibility for what they are doing. If we are going to seek to have transferred to the Minister the political control of the appointment of the General Manager, we are not allowing the commissioners to accept their full part of this responsibility, which is Aboriginal people.

Given that these people are Aboriginal administrators and are appointed to do a special task, we make a mockery of the whole thing if we say that, just because the Minister got himself into strife last year, because he made the wrong appointments to the Commission, who in turn engaged in this bastardry, we should transfer the responsibility straight back to the Minister. As Senate Tate pointed out last night, it is more to do with the fact that we are more fearful of some of the actions of Minister Hand than perhaps we were of any past Ministers, or will be of any future Minister. I believe that the Governments proposition does not recognise the proper development that should be allowed to happen for Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling has given an eloquent argument in favour of the Government's position on this matter. There is nothing in the Opposition's proposal which would prevent such bastardry-as Senator Tambling termed it-being exercised against the General Manager at some future date. In fact, what the Government proposes is-honourable senators may think it is somewhat paradoxical-a protection to a general manager against the sort of activity that went on in relation to the former general manager, Mr O'Brien, as characterised by Senator Tambling. In fact, by requiring the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) to take responsibility for the termination of an appointment, in terms of proposed new section 32g, one would not only have protection in terms of the statute but also, of course, ultimate responsibility to the Parliament. The Minister would have to take responsibility for and explain, when challenged in this chamber, his actions under section 32g. Therefore, there would be greater protection for a general manager facing the sorts of bastardry which Senator Tambling claims characterised the actions of the Commission in relation to Mr O'Brien. I think the inclusion of this clause by the Government provides some protection and, indeed, a barrier against that sort of malevolent action by the Commission, as part of the reconstruction of the Aboriginal Development Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has just said, in rebuttal of Senator Tambling's argument, could be restated in the following way: `We can only protect the General Manager by doing away with the concept of self-management'. That is what the Minister is saying. By giving the non-Aboriginal Minister authority, a general manager can be protected against excesses of Aboriginal commissioners. While I found what the commissioners did to Mr O'Brien last year unfair and malevolent, it was nevertheless within their capacity to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make several points. The Aboriginal Development Commission has operated since 1980, with the Commission selecting its own General Manager. I know of no good reason for that to change. The Minister has said that he wants it to change and that in the Government's view it would assist accountability. I cannot see how it would assist accountability. I cannot see the connection. The Minister then said that the amendments might cause complications in relation to clause 13. If that is so, if these amendments are successful and the Minister then wished us to reconsider the appropriateness of the proposed new section, we would hear argument. The Minister might then say he would be happier if we did not proceed in regard to proposed section 33 (2) when we consider that a little later, but there is nothing in his argument that adequately rebuts any of the arguments that I have put forward. If we are talking about Aboriginal self-management, and if we have any regard for the history of the Aboriginal Development Commission and the capacity of the Commission to appoint its own General Manager, it remains a valid point, and the amendments which we have proposed seek to maintain the status quo. For that reason we press them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not doubt Senator Tate's capacity or his integrity regarding this matter, but I doubt his knowledge of Aboriginals. What he is really saying is that the Aboriginal Development Commission cannot guarantee responsibility for its own accountability and that the only way that we will have accountability is to place a ministerial appointment in to the ADC. Senator Tate is falling into a very serious trap. Aboriginal people are very hurt by this. He is patronising the Aboriginal people. He is saying, `You haven't got the ability, you haven't got the capacity, and you haven't got the brains to guarantee accountability. We are going to put big brother in there to watch over you. You haven't been able to do it for 200 years and you are not going to do it for the next 200 years. We are going to hold your hand'. Senator Tate should not do that. He should give the Aboriginal people a go; he should let the Aboriginal people run their own organisation. They will make mistakes; a lot more mistakes will be made, but it is only by making mistakes that they are going to learn. The Aboriginal people are not going to learn anything if someone is appointed to the Commission to hold their hand and tell them what to do-someone who will make the decisions for them when they should be making the decisions themselves. They will fall back on that particular person and look to him instead of looking to themselves to make decisions. I know I am preaching to the converted when I am talking to Senator Coulter. He has said that we are supporting these amendments that will give self-determination, but I want to put on the record, and say to Senator Tate, that we must not patronise Aboriginals.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to add a few remarks to those that have been very cogently put in this debate on these clauses by Senator Peter Baume, my colleague Senator Boswell and, I understand, Senator Coulter of the Australian Democrats. It seems to me that what we have here is not merely the question to which most recently Senator Boswell has referred, but also a different question which the Government has failed to address. After all we have here a Commission the framework for the establishment of which is being set up by this Government, yet this Government appears to be professing so little faith in the product of its work that it is not prepared to endow that Commission with the power to appoint its own General Manager. I find this strange. The Minister for Justice has put forward an argument which is all very well as far as it goes but, as Senator Boswell has said, the failure by the Minister to accept the amendments put forward by the Opposition in this area really boils down to a lack of confidence in the people making up the Commission. With great respect, I think the Minister has not addressed that point and I would like to hear him, when responding, do so directly. Is the Minister reflecting a lack of confidence in the people who make up the Commission or is he not?

—All I am trying to establish is a way in which the Minister can be accountable to the Parliament for the appointment of the General Manager and the performance of his duties. It is a question, arising out of incidents in recent times, of looking at the termination of the appointment-if one likes to put it that way-of Mick O'Brien, which was spoken about by Senator Tambling. I believe one can make a case for the better protection of the General Manager, and a better method for enabling him to discharge his duties without fear of the undermining which was outlined by Senator Tambling, and there is better protection in the provisions of proposed new section 32g for termination of appointment, for which the Minister would be answerable to the Parliament. It is in relation to that that I believe the argument is best illustrated in favour of the clause put in by the Government which the Opposition is opposing. I do not think I can add greatly to the discussion on this particular matter, and I just indicate that the Government will be opposing that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to return to the words of Senator Boswell which I thought were absolutely appropriate to this whole debate. Unfortunately, underlying a lot of this debate there is an attitude of paternalism, and an unwillingness to trust Aboriginal people. I think Senator Collins made the point in his speech the other day, also very eloquently, that with respect to this whole package it may be that this legislation does not work-it may be that it does fail. But those of us who are supporting the package as a whole are making a judgment that, the Aboriginal people have to be given an opportunity to give it a go and they have to be trusted. It is no good simply going halfway. If we are fair dinkum about self-determination and self-management, that also means the right to fail as well as the right to succeed. Let us remember that there are many white proposals and structures which fail also.
—Spectacularly.
—Spectacularly so, as Senator Collins points out.
—How about the Western Australian Government?

—Yes, as Senator Stone says. One could perhaps reflect on the Queensland Government too while we are there. Let us just remember that failure is not a unique privilege of Aboriginal people, and the right to succeed or the right to fail, and the right to make mistakes, is something that must be granted to them. I see these series of amendments in that light. I also ask the Opposition to bear Senator Boswell's words very much in mind when we get to the debate on the main Bill, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Page 5, clause 12, proposed subsection 32a (4) lines 3 to 6, leave out the proposed subsection.

Honourable senators will note that we have circulated this amendment under the heading `Group 4-General Manager's Duty to Commission, not Minister'. It becomes easier to argue for it in the light of the vote that has just been taken on amendments (3) to (10), the last group of amendments that we have just dealt with, which make it clear that the General Manager is a creature of the Commission, not a creature of the Minister. What I propose in this amendment is that we should leave out proposed subsection 32a (4). That subsection might have been appropriate had the General Manager of the Commission been an agent of the Minister. It might have been partly appropriate, because the proposed subsection reads:

In spite of any policy determined or direction given by the Commission for the purpose of subsection (3), the General Manager shall, when requested by the Minister, provide information or advice to the Minister on any matter specified by the Minister.

I will separate the words `on any matter specified by the Minister' for one moment. Had the General Manager been an appointee of the Minister, there would have been an argument to say that he should have been required to report to the Minister in a general way, which this subsection envisages. But that subsection as it stands would make it clear that the General Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) is in a master/servant relationship-he is a servant of the Minister, not of the ADC. It would be the General Manager's duty really to tell on, to give information about, the very people for whom he works whenever a Minister asked. Such a proposal is a very gross intrusion upon the principle of self-management.

Without making too much of it, I ask honourable senators to direct their minds particularly to the words `on any matter specified by the Minister'. We argued about this matter earlier. I think Senator Coulter took me to task for the rather reductio ad absurdum example I used when I said, `You might be able to ask the General Manager about any information he may have gathered when shopping for the family groceries last week'. As the subsection is drafted, that would be possible. The subsection states that the General Manager must provide information or advice on any matter specified by the Minister. For the same reasons as we identified last night, we think that that is unduly wide. But in any event, in the light of the amendment to which we have just agreed, this subsection is no longer necessary or appropriate. Further, it creates the wrong relationship between the Commission and its chief officer. That is another reason why it should not be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst proposed new subsection 32a is extracted by the Opposition for another vote, nevertheless it forms part of proposed section 32. One has to keep in mind that, despite the vote that has been taken, what one is trying to achieve is a capacity for the Minister to be truly answerable to this Parliament in the ultimate political sense for the operations of the Aboriginal Development Commission. It is extremely difficult to do so if information which the Parliament is seeking cannot be provided to the Minister initially so that he can then make a response to the Parliament in its questions or in its general debate in relation to the operations of the Aboriginal Development Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I can say from my own experience over the last 12 months or so that there have been times when I have been utterly embarrassed and left stranded by my inability to answer many questions put by the Opposition relating to the operations of the Aboriginal Development Commission simply because the Minister had no capacity to require information to be sent across from the Commission. I can assure the Committee that we found it extremely difficult to overcome that problem. Honourable senators will recall that there were delays of weeks, and of months on some occasions, in trying to get information for the Senate in answer to questions or for its consideration in the various debates that took place. The fact is that the General Manager would be in a position to ensure that the Minister had the information at his request so that if the Parliament wished, as is its right, to hold the Minister accountable in the ultimate political sense for the operations of the Commission, then it has the information properly available to it. It is in that sense that the clause was drafted by the Government.

This proposed new subsection has a very important role in ensuring that the proper processes of accountability on the part of the Minister to this Parliament take place. After listening to Senator Peter Baume and recalling last night's debate I wonder whether it might be possible to amend the particular clause seeking information in the same terms as the Opposition's group 1 amendment was last night, so that the information which might be properly sought by the Minister should relate to or be about the operations of the Commission or about the Act. I make it quite clear that that is what is intended-the Minister should be able to obtain information about the operations of the Commission or about the Act. That might be done on the run. Perhaps we could hear what Senator Coulter has to say before deciding whether we should pursue that further amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be good if we could co-operate to resolve this issue. We agree with the goal which the Minister has stated in the arguments he has put. He has no disagreement from this side about the need for proper accountability and he had no disagreement from this side when he set out for us some of the difficulties he faced last year of which we were aware and with which we sympathised. But if this proposed subclause were written to require the Commission, when requested by the Minister, to provide information we would have no objection to it. If the Minister is proposing that he might amend it, perhaps he might consider amending it in two ways: first, to amend the last few words in the manner in which he has already suggested and, secondly, instead of the proposed new subsection saying that the General Manager shall do certain things it should say that the Commission shall do certain things. At that stage it may be possible to get agreement from this side of the chamber.

—Senator Peter Baume has pre-empted me. That was precisely the point I was going to make. My understanding was that the Minister could seek advice and information from the Commission. In the past, when that information has not been forthcoming promptly, the Commission has been derelict in its responsibility. I certainly support what Senator Baume has just said. The Minister has really addressed only one part of the concern about this-namely, the breadth of information and advice which can be obtained from the General Manager. The other part to which Senator Baume has just drawn our attention is the fact that information is obtainable from the General Manager and not the Commission. I would certainly be happier if the Government were prepared to look at inserting `Commission' rather than `General Manager' with or without the other word regarding the breadth or narrowness of the advice which the Minister may seek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am extremely attracted to this idea but it is already in the Bill. If honourable senators look at page 2 of the Bill as circulated they will find that it states:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Section 8 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by inserting after paragraph (e) the following paragraph:
`(ea) when requested by the Minister, to provide information or advice to the Minister on any matter specified by the Minister,';
So I guess we have already covered the capacity of the Commission to provide information. It is not in quite the mandatory terms of proposed new subsection 32a (4) which states in part:
shall, when requested . . . provide information . . .

I do not mind strengthening the clause in that way; I just indicate that, whilst the General Manager is on hand at all times, the Commission meets at irregular intervals. For that reason it might be more difficult to get the information in a timely way in order to assist the Parliament in its deliberations and to ensure the accountability of the Minister. But I can accept that, given Senator Coulter's indications, the proposed new subsection, as drafted, will not be carried. Therefore, if the clause were to read, `The Commission shall, when requested by the Minister, provide information or advice to the Minister about the operation of the Commission or about this Act', we could accept that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition agrees with the Minister and I take it that Senator Coulter also agrees. I think we have agreement around the chamber. I seek leave to withdraw my amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.
Amendment (by Senator Tate)-by leave-agreed to:
Page 5, clause 12, proposed subsection 32a (4), lines 3-6, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:
``(4) The Commission shall, when requested by the Minister, provide information or advice to the Minister about the operations of the Commission or about this Act.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Page 7, clause 14, lines 10 to 25, leave out the clause.

This is an amendment to clause 14 of the Bill. It seeks to leave out the clause which appears between lines 10 and 25 on page 7 of the Bill. The clause which is sought to be omitted relates to the estimates of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). That clause seeks to add to the ADC Act some new subsections. The effect of the new subsections is to provide extra power for the Minister-power which the Minister has not previously had-to determine and oversight the estimates developed within the Aboriginal Development Commission. For example, proposed new subsection 2 would provide that the money of the Commission shall not be spent, except in accordance with estimates of expenditure approved by the Minister.

Subsection 3, if passed, would provide that the amount spent by the Commission in relation to matters covered by an item in estimates approved by the Minister may differ from the amount allocated only within certain narrow limits. Proposed subsection 4, if passed, would provide that nothing in the above subsections empowers the Commission to spend amounts in relation to matters covered by the estimates approved by the Minister that exceed in total the total amount of expenditure provided for by those estimates. This brings the whole estimates process of the ADC under ministerial control. Honourable senators will appreciate that subsection 2 provides that the estimates shall be such and such, as approved by the Minister. Subsection 3 talks about estimates approved by the Minister. Subsection 4 limits the capacity of the ADC to vary those estimates.

When I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs one of the things that made the Department so good-it was a splendid Department to work with in those days-was the fact that we had a global Budget. One of the great virtues of the global budgeting process was that I could move money around after consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I could respond to need as it arose. When the ADC was created in 1980 there was no provision such as the proposed provision in that Act. No previous Minister has found it necessary to seek such close controls over the estimates process.

I do not wish to bore the Committee, but again and again we return to the theme of Aboriginal self-management. If that is what we are on about it is really important to question why this new constraint will be necessary. The things that occurred last year really occurred as a consequence of the great disturbances following the dismissal of certain commissioners. They were the consequences of poor decisions made by commissioners. The answer is to appoint better commissioners. The answer is not to try to seek to amend the ADC Act to tie up the estimates setting process of the ADC in a way which has never been done previously. It provides that the Minister must approve all estimates. That then binds the ADC completely.

I have to say something else to the Committee. The standard organs of government-the central control organs of government-have never liked the ADC. They do not like statutory commissions. A statutory commission whose goal is self-management will not be liked. I know that the Minister may tell us that certain central groups within Government when asked to report to the ADC managed to report in ways that sought to bring the ADC back under standard public service control. That is not what the self-management ideal is about. It is not a question of our seeking to do away with something that exists. It is a question of our seeking to ask the Government why it is necessary to extend ministerial control over the estimates process of the ADC. That is the question.

Our amendment which seeks to leave out the clause would once again, as with previous amendments, merely seek to maintain the status quo ante. The ADC has been the flagship of Aboriginal self-management. It remains so. We have to be very careful about any exercise which seeks to constrain that Aboriginal self-management. If there have been errors-and indeed there have been-we should sack the commissioners and appoint better ones. We should not change the system unless there is an absolute need to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Baume really summed up the problem that we are facing in this particular debate by saying that we are merely trying to restore the status quo ante. It is all very well to accept that the chamber has voted for the motion for the second reading of the Bill and then clause by clause undo everything that is sought to be achieved by the Bill. I think the point has come in this particular debate when we are really onto a crucial nub in the reconstruction of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) as undertaken by the Government in good faith following the reports that were sought by this Parliament into the operations of the Aboriginal Development Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that if one looks at the special audit report on the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aborigi-nal Affairs one finds the comment-I think I read it last night-about the way in which the ADC is required to provide the Minister with annual estimates of proposed expenditure in such form as he directs but is not required to obtain his approval of the estimates. That is the difficulty that was taken up by the Department of Finance in its report on the financial management of the Aboriginal Development Commission dated March 1989. At the end of the report it recommended:

It is recommended that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs exercise greater ministerial authority over the Commission. In respect of the approval of the Commission's estimates, this would have an immediate effect on the operations of the Commission and would ensure that the Commission's programs at least reflect the priorities of the Government's policies. It is therefore recommended that the Minister for Finance write to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs suggesting he consider:
(a) the means by which the Commission may be required to provide him with estimates for approval (including for the remainder of this financial year);
(b) advice of the financial policies to be followed in the administration and control of the Commission's programs; and
(c) a Corporate Plan for endorsement.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in statements of 11 April this year undertook to accept the various reports made into the apparent breakdown in the administration of elements of Aboriginal affairs at the national level in this country. We have brought into the Parliament a Bill which seeks to carry into statutory form the recommendations arising out of those reports which were sought by the Parliament. It is the Parliament that insisted that these investigations into the administration of Aboriginal affairs be undertaken.

Whilst we are not absolutely bound to implement everything that an Auditor- General or a Department of Finance report recommends, quite clearly and properly the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs recognised that a good faith response to these reports was required. They did so and we have the clauses in the Bills before us. I say Bills because in the passage of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill 1989, which was achieved last night, we accepted amendments put forward by the Opposition, and in relation to the estimates procedure for the Institute the integrity of which Senator Peter Baume quite genuinely expressed a high regard for, Senator Baume inserted the following clause:
Estimates

``35b. (1) The Council shall prepare estimates, in such form as the Minister directs, of the receipts and expenditure of the Institute for each financial year and, if the Minister so directs, for any other period specified by the Minister, and the Council shall submit estimates so prepared to the Minister not later than such date as the Minister directs.
``(2) The money of the Institute, other than money held on trust, shall not be spent otherwise than in accordance with estimates of expenditure approved by the Minister.''.

The Opposition has already thought it compatible with the integrity of the Institute and the devising of the programs on which it would expend money appropriated by this Parliament that its estimates of expenditure be approved by the Minister. So I believe that the proposition put forward by the Government that the estimates of expenditure in relation to the ADC should be approved by the Minister is not really so radical and cannot be portrayed as undermining the integrity and the self-management ethos of the Commission. It is a matter which is compatible apparently with maintaining that integrity and yet obviously allows for the Minister to play the sort of role which the reports sought by this Parliament indicated was proper for him, if these elements of the national provision of moneys for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander purposes are to be properly dealt with in a way which is accountable to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several things that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has said require a response. First of all, the Opposition, having accepted the verdict of the Senate on the second reading, is not against any change to the Aboriginal Development Commission Act and our amendments do not seek to undo the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill clause by clause. I remind the Committee that this Bill has 20 clauses. I have very quickly gone through clauses 1, 2, 3, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 13, 16, 17 ,18, 19 and 20. As far as the Opposition is concerned, we are not seeking to amend them; they do bring changes into the Act. So it is not correct that we are undoing it clause by clause. We are seeking, wherever we think that Aboriginal management has been unacceptably limited, to change it in those terms. The Minister has said that the Parliament sought change. He is quite correct. The Parliament did seek change, but the details and nature of that change have to be looked at by the Parliament when they are presented, and our duty in this chamber is to look at the statute, look at the clauses, and try to do the best job we can.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister raised an analogy with the Institute of Aboriginal Studies and made the point that last night we proposed an amendment, which was accepted, which gave some direct ministerial control over the estimates of the Institute. He is quite correct, but the analogy is not an appropriate one. The Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies will operate independently of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission now. It is not, and never has been, a flagship, as it were, of self-management, it has been an academic institution with an academic task. It has always operated in direct relationship with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Its funding has always been departmental or direct from government. It is one of the portfolio agencies in direct relationship with the Minister. The clause to which the Committee agreed last night was an entirely appropriate clause. While it was appropriate for the Institute, we believe it is inappropriate for the Aboriginal Development Commission. I will not reiterate all the arguments, but I believe that each of the points that the Minister raised in rebuttal can in turn be rebutted. I believe that the amendment is an appropriate one.

TALK.START.PARA: —One point which neither the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) nor Senator Peter Baume picked up on, and which seems to me to be relevant here, is that the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill deals with the Aboriginal Development Commission transition. That circumstance is unlike the circumstance which has obtained in the past and unlike the circumstance which, presumably, will obtain in the future once the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and its dependent organs are fully operational. For the same reasons which I stated in relation to Senator Baume's amendment to clause 10a (3), it seems to me that under these transitional circumstances it is more appropriate that there be closer liaison between the Minister and the Commission. I do not see that in this instance as intruding into the matter of self-management and self-determination because it is a transitional circumstance. They may convince the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that ATSIC is not appropriate. Senator Coulter and I know from our travels in the bush together that ATSIC was by no means universally accepted. Ninety per cent of the people we talked to in the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs were not convinced that ATSIC was the appropriate way to go. Even those that were in limbo wanted more consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: The ATSIC Bill may not get up. We have to look at the Bill in front of us today. That Bill gives the Minister control of all expenditure that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) has within its power to deal out. The amendment, which relates to page 7, clause 14, lines 10 to 25, depowers the ADC, which is the flagship of Aboriginal development in Australia. As Senator Coulter agreed to our last amendment on the grounds that great harm would otherwise have been done to self-management, self-determination, I think that to be consistent he should support this amendment. Clearly, our amendment will give Aboriginals greater self-determination and self-management.

We see the measure as just another ministerial attempt to control the ADC; just another attempt to put the Minister in control of a development commission which should be providing not only money for small business and businesses for the Aboriginal community but also an opportunity for Aboriginals to get business experience out in the field, for which it lends money, and in the decision-making process. As Senator Coulter pointed out to Senator Tate a few moments ago, we cannot have it both ways. Either we want self-management or we do not want self-management. The Liberals, the Nationals and the Democrats support self-management, but Senator Coulter cannot have two bob each way. We cannot put the Minister in there and let him virtually run the Department. He knows as well as I do that under those circumstances people will not take the responsibility: they will not take their job seriously. They will say, `What's the use of coming down here, apart from getting a trip out of it? Ultimately the Minister will make the decisions. He will be in control of the Budget and we will be but black tokens sitting here putting our rubber stamp on a ministerial decision'. I ask Senator Coulter not to have two bob each way but to join with us in our amendment and go 100 per cent for self-determination and self-management.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would agree with Senator Boswell that this is a difficult area. It is drawing somewhat of a long bow to deny the fact that this Bill is predicated on the assumption that ATSIC will become operational. If, as Senator Boswell has indicated-for whatever reason-ATSIC does not succeed in getting through and does not come into operation, the whole structure of the administration of Aboriginal affairs will have to be reassessed all over again. We would be looking at a new structure with new legislation and new Bills. Under those circumstances I think that we would be seeking something different, but we must proceed on the assumption that the Bills are being presented as a package. They foretell certain things happening, the shape of which is now being determined by our considerations at the committee stage. ``15. After section 39 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:
Finance Directions
`39a. (1) The Commission shall prepare and submit to the Minister written directions, not inconsistent with this Act or the regulations, about the administration of the Commission's finances.

`(2) The directions may apply, adopt or incorporate, with or without modifications, directions given under the Audit Act 1902 by the Minister for Finance, or the Secretary to the Department of Finance, being such directions as in force at a particular time or as in force from time to time.
`(3) The Minister may approve directions prepared under subsection (1).

`(5) Without limiting the operation of the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Commission shall ensure that copies of the approved Finance Directions are available for inspection and purchase at each office of the Commission.
`(6) The General Manager shall cause notice of the approval of Finance Directions under this section to be published in the Gazette.
`(7) In this section, ``approved Finance Direction'' means a direction approved by the Minister under subsection (3).'.''.

This amendment seeks to leave out clause 15 which appears at page 7 of the Bill, for the purpose of inserting thereafter a new section. Clause 15, as drafted, relates to ministerial finance directions. It provides that the Minister shall give to the Commission written directions not inconsistent with this Act about the administration of the Commission's finances. It goes on to say certain things about the finance directions. The Opposition has no objection to appropriate finance directions being given to the Aboriginal Development Commission. The question arises: what should be the structure under which they are given? How should they be given and what should happen to the lines of authority?

We believe it is desirable, consistent with the principle of Aboriginal self-management, that the finance directions should be acceptable to government. We have no objection to that, but consistent with Aboriginal self-management we believe the Commission itself should be asked to prepare its finance directions and seek to have them accepted. That would require the Commission to prepare finance directions which complied with the general structure of finance directions. The Commission would then present them to the Minister and would have them approved by government. It seems that if that were done the aims of the Government would be met-that is, the Commission would operate under a proper set of finance directions, but in the name of self-management it could have had a proper role in preparing those directions.

The section we seek to have inserted is designed to give the ADC some say in the kind of ministerial finance directions that could be made to it. Again, the issue is one of just how serious the Government is about Aboriginal self-management. We are quite serious that the Commission should have proper finance directions. I draw to the attention of the Committee that the proposed section to be added by the Opposition, which is contained in the circulated amendments, is quite extensive. The first part of our proposed amendment is in these terms:
`39A. (1) The Commission shall prepare and submit to the Minister written directions, not inconsistent with this Act or the regulations, about the administration of the Commission's finances.
I think that is a proper role to play. The second part of our proposed amendment is as follows:

`(2) The directions may apply, adopt or incorporate, with or without modifications, directions given under the Audit Act 1902 by the Minister for Finance, or the Secretary to the Department of Finance . . .
So the Commission will have a point of reference to which to go when it is preparing those finance directions. Then we provide:
`(3) The Minister may approve directions prepared under subsection (1).
Because we wish to be appropriately responsible in this matter, we then provide:
`(4) The Commission shall comply with an approved Finance Direction even if it is inconsistent with the corporate plan.

We have done that to make sure that we pick up the point made earlier by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), that it is not appropriate for a corporate plan to be brought up which in some way is inconsistent with proper accountability within government.

Then we provide that the Commission should ensure that copies of the approved finance directions should be publicly available for inspection and purchase at each office. There should be nothing secret about them. We also provide:
`(6) The General Manager shall cause notice of the approval of Finance Directions under this section to be published in the Gazette.

So the directions would be published in the most official organ of government. We then say what we mean by `approved finance direction'. We have tried to ensure that the finance directions which are prepared shall be adequate, proper and consistent with those required elsewhere in government. But we have tried to say, in the name of Aboriginal self-management, `Let them be prepared by the Commission and approved by the Minister-by the government of the day'. We believe that it is a very proper goal of government that there should be finance directions and that they should provide, as it were, a set of standards against which the Commission shall operate. We believe that they should be present but that they should be prepared, if possible, from within the Commission. That is the purpose of the amendment which I have moved on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Although I do not imagine that there will be any conflict at the end of the day with the finance directions that emerge, to insert this clause as proposed by the Government in the Bill is an eloquent statement of a lack of confidence in the Commission and the capacity of the Commission. This is one of those difficult interface situations where the requirements of public accountability require there to be finance directions.
