The Opposition has moved these amendments together because there are a very large number of amendments for the Committee to consider. It would make life very difficult if we were to consider all of them individually. I appreciate Senator Coulter's point that this may make it more difficult for him, but there is logic in the grouping of these amendments. I say to Senator Coulter, in order to assist him, that these amendments are mostly clause 7 amendments as well as an amendment to clause 8 on page 8 of the Bill. They all relate to the functions of the Commission. There can be few things more important than the statutory declaration of the functions of the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The Opposition believes it is important to propose the necessary amendments to ensure that these functions are appropriate and correct. I remind Senator Coulter of something he said earlier. He put to us that, in his view, it was very likely that this Commission would be in place some time in the foreseeable future. He also put to us the argument that because of that one did not need to agree to certain other amendments to the Aboriginal Development Commission Act, but that argument is the very reason why it is now important to look at all the proposals in this enormous Bill and examine whether or not we wish to alter any of them.

Our amendment No. 2 proposes that on page 7, clause 7, we should leave out the words, `including programs conducted by bodies other than the Commission', so the clause would then read, `to monitor the effectiveness of programs for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders'. Let us spend a moment in committee examining what would be the effect of that clause as it is drafted, and what would be the consequence of agreeing to the amendment. The clause as drafted would give the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission the capacity to sit in judgment, by way of monitoring its effectiveness, on any program conducted by any organ or body or group or government in relation to Aboriginal matters-in fact, any program which could affect Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders, even if it was not a program specifically designed for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. This would enable ATSIC to sit in judgment on other programs within the Department of Employment, Education and Training which are not primarily Aboriginal programs at all but which may have several Aboriginal clients. Departments would continue, even if it is not proposed for ATSIC to do so, to report to Ministers, who are responsible to Parliament.

It is very strange to imagine the situation of a department of state, for which there is a Minister appointed under the Constitution who is responsible for that Department's programs, and the Minister suddenly finds that he has a very ill-defined relationship with ATSIC because, under proposed clause 7 (b), the new Commission would have the capacity to look at any program anywhere in Australia affecting Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. This clause, as proposed, would enable ATSIC to sit in judgment on State governments and State government programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the whole idea.

—It certainly would have that effect. The Opposition has concluded that that really is too much. We are aware of the constitutional proprieties that exist as a result of the Constitution, particularly those clauses which establish Ministers of state and give appropriate relationships for Ministers of state with the departments they administer. We do not oppose the proposal that there should be a function of the new Commission-if it is the wish of the Parliament to appoint a new Commission-which should relate to the monitoring of the effectiveness of programs for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders. It would not be our intention to see this whole subclause deleted, and we have not so proposed. All we have proposed is that those words, which take the function a bit too far, should come out. That is the first of our amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The second of our amendments is to proposed subclause 7 (c). Honourable senators will see that we propose to insert some words into that subclause. Madam Temporary Chairman, I remind you that we have moved these amendments together, so I will go through them seriatim. We propose to insert the words `when requested by the Minister'. Consider the clause as it is written. It states:
to develop policy proposals to meet national, State, Territory and regional needs and priorities of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders;

Again, we think the Commission should remain within its own powers and functions as laid down in this statute, but when one reads proposed clause 7 (c), it suggests, to me anyhow, that it would be possible for the Commission to seek to develop policy proposals for the State of New South Wales in relation to State departments. With great respect, that is a matter for government to government negotiation. The Federal Government has been at some pains to say to us, `Do not regard ATSIC as some kind of Aboriginal parliament. Do not regard ATSIC in the way some of its critics do.' This clause as drafted, is the very thing about which people have been worrying.

What would happen if I were the Minister responsible for Aboriginal affairs in New South Wales and I suddenly got a phone call from someone in ATSIC to say, `Under sub-clause 7 (b) we intend to monitor the effectiveness of what you are on about'. I ask Senator Knowles to imagine this in the State of Western Australia. Under subclause 7 (c) I might suddenly get a phone call to say, `We intend, at Commonwealth level, to develop policy proposals'. It is not just a question of identifying unmet need. The identification of unmet need is another matter. It is a question of actually developing policy proposals to meet State needs and priorities of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders.

Again, the Opposition wants to make it clear that it does not oppose the idea of the Commission having the function of developing policy proposals; but we think it should be limited to when it is requested to do so by the Minister. Some of these actions will involve the Minister. They will involve him in discussions with his colleagues within other governments and departments, and at other levels of government. We think that the Minister-he or she-should at least have a role in identifying these policy proposals, certainly as they relate to areas outside the portfolio.

The third amendment in this group is amendment No. 4. I remind the Committee that we have put aside consideration of our amendment No. 1, which relates to the preamble, by agreement. Amendment 4 is to subclause 7 (d). That subclause, as drafted, worries the Opposition quite considerably. We suggest that subclause 7 (d) will need to be deleted and replaced by another. The amendment is designed to avoid the need for the proposed ATSIC to form or enter into arrangements which will enable it to establish any kind of hegemony in Aboriginal affairs. We are not being fanciful in our concern about this. If it has a function to assist, advise and cooperate with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, organisations and individuals at national, State, Territory and regional levels-that is what is proposed by the Government-that is altogether too broad. We propose instead that that paragraph should be deleted and there should be inserted in its place a different paragraph (d), which should read as follows:

in connection with matters that are functions of the Commission because of other provisions of this Act, but not in any other circumstances, to assist, advise and co-operate with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, organisations and individuals.

We are not limiting unduly the operations or potential operations of ATSIC. We are saying that in connection with any matters that are functions of the Commission because of other provisions of this Act it should be able to do certain things. We think that that is a proper and necessary amendment as well. Our fourth amendment-that is circulated amendment No. (5), which is part of this group-now relates to subclause 7 (e). I emphasise again that we are concentrating on the functions because this is a critical part of the whole ATSIC proposal. (Extension of time granted).
I remind the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) of the old Latin phrase `Eheu fugaces, postume postume labuntur anni', which means that I was Minister a long time ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's all Latin to me.

—It is contrary to the Standing Orders to use another language too, but no-one picked me up. The next amendment is to subclause 7 (e). This is the same kind of problem, but this time it talks about establishing consultative arrangements. We have proposed the deletion of this subclause because we think the function of establishing extra consultative arrangements is an incidental function. We think further that there is no need for the Commission to set up elaborate or overly intrusive consultative arrangements. What is more, we think that there is every reason why the Commission should not go down that road. One of the problems will be the acceptability and respectability of the new Commission. That does not only include its acceptability within Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, but its acceptability within the rest of Australia. I want to see the Government of Queensland able to deal with this new Commission if it comes into existence without a great sense of threat or fear. I want to see the Government of Western Australia able to do the same thing, and the Government of South Australia, and so on. This involves not only goodwill but a statute in which people can have confidence. Our amendment No. (5), which I have already moved, will leave out paragraph (1) (e). The sixth amendment which we have circulated, and which we have moved, is in relation to subclause 7 (f). We propose that that subclause be deleted and be replaced by a new subparagraph (f) which would read:

SPEECH.PARA: when requested by the Minister, to advise the Minister on matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs;
I invite honourable senators just to compare the existing subclause 7 (f) and the one which we propose to put in its place. In the Bill paragraph (f) reads:
to advise the Minister on:
(i) matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, including the administration of legislation; and-
I interpolate: why is that there?-
(ii) the co-ordination of the activities of other Commonwealth bodies that affect Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

TALK.START.PARA: —That covers the whole waterfront.

—Precisely. We think the amendment to subclause 7 (f) is essential to ensure that ATSIC does not have a role in the administration of legislation. Honourable senators should just think about that, look at it as it is presently presented and think what it means. The administration of legislation is a matter for a Minister of State properly appointed in pursuance of the relevant section of the Australian Constitution, who takes advice, as is normal, from a Department of State. It follows, once we have accepted that that is the model under which we operate, that the adoption of this particular amendment would be a vote for the retention-when I say `the amendment', I mean the amendment which the Opposition has proposed-of a Department of State because we believe that there has to be a Department of State, a Department of Aboriginal Affairs of this State, or else the assumption by some other Department of State, perhaps the mega department of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, of the traditional role of adviser to the Minister, but it must not be the new Commission. The new Commission cannot stand in relation to the Minister as if it were a Department of State. This is why we have proposed this amendment to subclause 7 (f).

SPEECH.PARA: We have not just sought to delete it; we have sought to replace it with what we think is the reasonable function-that is, `when requested by the Minister, to advise the Minister on matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs'. That is to say, we still place the Minister as the person appointed by the Constitution, but the Commission becomes one adviser to the Minister in a rather more proper role. We think that ATSIC in this kind of sense should not consider itself as being able to operate at large in giving and promoting advice, but that it should do so only when the Government asks for that advice.

The seventh circulated amendment, which is a part of this group, is in relation to heritage protection and is proposed subclause 7 (h). Subclause 7 (h), as it is written, requires the Commission, as one of its functions:

. . . to take such reasonable action as it thinks necessary to protect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural material and information, being material or information that is considered sacred or otherwise significant by Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders;

The deletion of this subclause is necessary to make it clear that ATSIC would not have a maverick role, as it were, in the protection of Aboriginal heritage which seems to be provided by this rather open-ended subclause. The matter is one for the Minister, advised by his Department, to take action on under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act and in accordance with the specific procedures set out within that Act. I just remind the Committee that the Senate Select Committee into the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs looked at this ATSIC legislation and reported at paragraph 2.43 through to 2.47 that subclause 7 (h) would actually interfere with the functions of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. We have already considered and agreed to that legislation. We have amended it appropriately, and we have included an amendment relating to heritage protection. I put it to the Committee that this particular paragraph as proposed by the Government in the Bill will still have the defect that the Senate Select Committee identified and about which it unanimously reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to those questions is yes, yes, and yes. I will come back to the last one in due course.

—I will, indeed, Mr President. As I said, the answers are yes to the first question, yes to the second, and yes to the third; and as to the last question, if it is related to my portfolio I will deal with it. I draw the Senate's attention to an article which appeared in the Cairns Post on 24 August and which was headed `Kidston mine pours one millioneth ounce of gold'. The black type subheading states:

ANSWER.PARA: Far North Queensland is a prospective area for intensive mineral development, and the number of mining proposals currently being evaluated indicates there could be considerable mining expansion early next century.
The article goes on to say:
The Minister for Mines, Energy and Northern Development, Mr Martin Tenni, said that the mining industry was in a healthy state and would stay that way for decades.

The article quotes from Mr Tenni's speech, in which he particularly picks up the strong performance of the goldmining industry in north Queensland. Not only does Mr Tenni sprout what I believe to be accurate rhetoric about the future of the mining industry in north Queensland and of the goldmining industry in north Queensland, but he also gives some empirical evidence to back up that rhetoric. He cites for example the Red Dome prospect, in which an open cut goldmine has proven up 8.7 million tonnes of high quality ore. He said in his speech:
Gold continues to be the strongest performer in the region . . . There have been three major gold mines commissioned in the past two years and a number of proposed mines are being evaluated.

He talks about a mine project by Barrick Mines and Pancontinental at Croydon. He talks about a consortium of the Macquarie Bank Ltd, the Queensland Industry Development Corporation, and PAMP of Switzerland which is developing a gold refinery at Cairns. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN EMBASSY IN CHILE: MIGRATION INQUIRIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of a dramatic fall in the number of migration inquiries to the Australian Embassy in Chile since October 1988? Has this reduction in applications been due to restrictions on access to the Embassy? Can the Minister confirm that two Chilean military police officers are stationed at the Embassy gates and are able to request the identity cards of those Chileans entering the Embassy?
—Order! An honourable senator is asking a question.

—Does the Minister agree that this could be a significant deterrent to people wishing to apply to come to Australia under the special humanitarian assistance program? What action can the Government take to ensure that potential applicants are not deterred from making their applications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for his question, and for the advance notice which he gave me of it as I have been able to obtain a reply. I am aware of the change in interest in Chile in migration to Australia. Last year saw a substantial drop in inquiries. From October 1987 to June 1988 inquiries reached 63,415, but in the same period the following year, up to June 1989, 29,037 inquiries were recorded. That is a decrease of about 54 per cent. But I think we also have to take into account that an interest is being shown within Australia by Chilean refugees who wish to return home. I tend to think both sets of figures reflect a growing optimism in the normalisation process as Chile moves down the path towards a restitution of full democracy. As the honourable senator would know, these developments are against the background of a presidential plebiscite held in October 1988 which resulted in a loss for the Pinochet forces, and in July this year 85 per cent of Chilean voters overwhelmingly approved a significant constitutional reform.

ANSWER.PARA: On the second matter, I do not believe that this reduction is due to restricted access to the Embassy. On the third question I cannot confirm immediately whether military police are still stationed at the gates of the Embassy. They were stationed there some time ago at the request of the Australian Ambassador as threats were received against the Embassy itself and against Australian nationals in Chile. The presence of the police officers at the entrance of the Embassy could deter special humanitarian applicants from personally presenting their papers. However, they are not obliged to lodge applications in this way; they may use the mailing system or lodge them with associated international organisations which, in many cases, not only assist in the completion of applications but are able to pass them on to Australian officials. As to the last part of the question, I am not aware of any arrangements that are deterring people from lodging such applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Approximately what percentage of the pilots involved in the current industrial dispute learnt to fly in the Defence Force at the expense of taxpayers? If the airline pilots are given a pay rise of $20,000 to $40,000, does the Minister expect such a pay rise to affect morale amongst Defence Force pilots? Does the Minister expect that such a massive increase in pay sought by the airline pilots, representing more than the median weekly wage just in the increases alone, will have any effect on the rate at which the Defence Force loses pilots who have cost taxpayers a great deal to train?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Royal Australian Air Force does not keep records of its personnel once they have departed, so there are no figures available to say how many former RAAF pilots may now be in the employment of domestic airlines. Having said that, I think the general concern of the Air Force over the years has been recruitment by Qantas Airways Ltd rather than by domestic airlines. I am led to believe that most of the people who have separated-to use the term the Defence Force uses-from the RAAF have gone in that direction rather than to the domestic airlines. Nonetheless, if the pilots were to be successful in achieving a massive increase, such as the one they have sought in this dispute, no doubt that would have an effect on the rate of pilot separation from the Air Force.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has worked hard to make conditions for Defence Force personnel as attractive as possible. But, in the commercial world of airlines, it has been difficult to hold the line. Australian Defence Force pilots have received wage increases in line with the bounds of the accord. I dare say that, like all Australian workers, they would be outraged if the pilots were able to achieve, outside the system, a claim which is as massive in its scope as outlined by Senator McLean in his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. When will the Government introduce a loan Bill for 1989?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be introducing a loan Bill in this financial year. The reason for that is that there is no necessity for a loan Bill. In the past the need for a loan Bill has derived from the legal requirement that expenditures from the Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF) may not exceed the revenues available to it. And, to the extent that there are any shortfalls in revenues, balancing the CRF therefore requires the charging of expenditures to, or reimbursement of CRF from, the Loan Fund, where they can be financed out of loan raisings. In other words, it is a sort of bridging financial provision within a financial year. There will be no need for such a bridging financial provision in this financial year because there will be a Budget surplus estimated to be above $9 billion at the end of the financial year and at no time during the financial year is it expected that there will be any need for a financing mechanism such as a loan Bill.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the loan Bill was never anything more than a bridging financing mechanism. It did not of itself authorise the expenditure of any money. But the Opposition, in the hope of scoring a few cheap political points, in every year that I can remember in the life of the present Government and back into the 1970s, used to pretend that the loan Bill was of crucial importance. Three years ago, I think, I introduced provisions to make a loan Bill a piece of standing legislation instead of a piece of annual legislation, but that was resisted by would-be big noters and the troglodytes in the Opposition as being some dirty trick that the Government was trying to play to deprive the Parliament of its power to scrutinise expenditure-all of which was total nonsense, like most of the words that pour out of the mouths of members of the Opposition, and was absolutely without foundation.

However, the more important point is the fact that there will be no loan Bill this year. This breaks new ground in Australia. I have not been able to find out in a brief time whether there has been a loan Bill every year since Federation. There has certainly been a loan Bill every year since the early 1950s. That is because there had never been a Budget surplus since the early 1950s until this Government produced one in the 1986-87 financial year. This year we will be producing a Budget surplus of such magnitude that, even within the financial year, the Consolidated Revenue Fund will not need any supplementation to meet the normal situation-that is, that Commonwealth outlays within any financial year occur before the full offsetting revenues are collected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Resources endorse the view expressed by his colleague Mr Milton in the House of Representatives on 30 August that the Government is now running a two-uranium mine policy and that the prospects are that there will be less mining of uranium in the future than there is at present?

—I have not seen Mr Milton's views, and nor has he contacted me about them, of what the Government's uranium policy is. The Government's uranium policy is well understood in this chamber. If I need to go through it again I will. My colleagues are saying, `Please don't; we have heard it a thousand times before'. It is, after all, a three-mines policy. Within the capacity of those mines there is the ability to escalate production to meet predicted world demand in the foreseeable future.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. What are the predictions made by the Minister's Department about the level of uranium mining in the years immediately ahead?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a ready reckoner on those predictions; so I will make an approximation off the top of my head and, if necessary, give the honourable senator a more detailed breakdown in the future. As I understand it, the current situation is that there is a supply of uranium overhanging the world market at present. That has put a downward pressure on prices. The expected future development of nuclear power generation in Japan, for example, is under a substantial question mark at this stage-that is, whether there will be new capacity brought on line.

ANSWER.PARA: At this stage there is some doubt as to what the nuclear future will be in the United States. There appears to be little doubt as to what the nuclear future will be in France because it is committed to a very strong nuclear program. There is a uranium supply available to the market through Canada, southern Africa, Australia and, no doubt, other places as well. Essentially they are the three major centres of supply. The current and immediate situation seems to be that the market will be overhung with supply.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in Wednesday's Australian Financial Review quoting the Liberal member for Goldstein, Mr Ian Macphee, on the question of industrial relations in Australia? In the article Mr Macphee describes Opposition policies encouraging employers and employees to opt out of the formalised industrial relations system as fanciful and the Opposition's support for secret ballots as a fetish. Mr Macphee goes on to say in the article-this is contrary to Opposition claims-that in his 25 years of experience in industrial relations he has never known such a propitious time for action by management at a decentralised level. Can the Minister comment on Mr Macphee's views and how they relate to the Government's industrial relations policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Macphee's views have been well known to me and everybody else for a long period. Whether one agrees with his views or not he has far more experience in industrial relations issues than anyone else in the Opposition. To that extent his views must be taken seriously. I do not know whether I would go so far to say that all elements of Opposition policies are fanciful. I think that a lot of them are, but not all of them.
—Some are stupid.

—Someone interjected that they are silly. Some are fanciful and some are not. In some circles on the Opposition side there is a realistic attempt to grapple with contemporary industrial relations issues. While there is a realistic attempt for some people to grapple with those issues in the Opposition, it is almost impossible for a Government spokesman to grapple with an Opposition view because it changes every day.
—What rubbish!

—The Opposition's policy changed about three times yesterday. Opposition industrial relations policy is `what you see is what you get depending on whom you are watching on television or listening to on radio'. Senator Chaney has always had difficulty disciplining the Senate Opposition here but he has also not had much success in disciplining his shadow ministerial colleagues or himself on the question of developing an industrial relations policy because he has changed his own views a few times in the past week.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Beahan asked me about Mr Macphee's comment that the Opposition's support for secret ballots in respect of strikes was a fetish. I do not know whether it is a fetish but that is not a bad word. I had some discussions in Britain in July when there was a bus and underground transport strike in London. Britain has provisions whereby there has to be a secret ballot before people go on strike in some organisations. They get a lock-in effect-that is, once a decision is made to go on strike it is very hard to get out of it. That is one of the difficulties which the Thatcher Government has with its industrial relations policy which, in some respects, Opposition spokesmen aspire to emulate. If we look at its industrial relations policy we should look at the level of increase in wages in Britain in the last year compared with the increase that has taken place in Australia. We see some of their problems. Ultimately, we see that Mr Macphee is probably right to describe some of these things in Opposition policies as a fetish.

The third issue which Senator Beahan touched on in his question-by the way, it was not a Dorothy Dix question; it came to me completely out of the blue-related to a comment made by Mr Macphee. It was a thoughtful and intelligent question which therefore produces a thoughtful and intelligent answer, which I am in the course of giving. Mr Macphee said that it was a most propitious time and there had been no more propitious time in the last 25 years for action by management in various enterprises to deal with many of the problems confronting the industrial relations area, particularly the question of productivity in the work place. Mr Macphee is totally right about that. As I have pointed out to the Senate on several occasions, in the last couple of weeks there are many companies that are taking advantage of those propitious opportunities. But there are others that are not. I might illustrate the point.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —These interjections are fantastic; they are coming from all directions. Each one of the people making them represents a different point of view in the Opposition. They are all over the place and are impossible to deal with.
—It is costing millions of dollars a day, and what are you doing?

—Senator Lewis has been strangely quiet until now. Mr Macphee is absolutely right about the question of the time being propitious and a lot of companies are taking advantage of it, but a lot are not. A senior executive of one of the biggest companies in Australia said to me the night before last, `I went to the United States but before I went I told a division of my company to fix a productivity and industrial relations problem'. He said that they did not do it. Management did not take the opportunity. It is all very well to come in here and play goodies and baddies in industrial relations but it requires an effort on all sides. What Mr Macphee has said is correct. The time is propitious. The tide taken at the flood leads on to greater things-greater things which are, sadly, not within the imagination of the Opposition.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and follows his very cheery answer of a moment ago. Does the Government support the management of the airlines entering into discussions with the pilots to enable some of these great advances that he has described to be made in the airline industry? Does the Government support discussions on obtaining productivity improvements from the pilots in return for wage increases?

—As I said yesterday, of course the Government supports talks between the airlines and the pilots on resolving these issues. But it is not the Government's job to shackle the airlines in saying to them that they have got to have these talks if the pilots say, `Before those talks can take place, we will not consider anything else but a 30 per cent wage claim and we will not consider productivity issues'. That has been their position right from the beginning and, as I understand, it still is.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question which follows on from the Minister's statement that it is not the Government's job to shackle the airlines. I ask the Minister to give a complete and unequivocal assurance to the Senate that the Government will in no way shackle the management of the airlines in entering into discussions of the sort that I have just indicated in my question.

—I will give that undertaking, except in this respect: right from the beginning the Government has said that any claim by the pilots dealt with by their former employers, the airlines, has to be dealt with consistently with the decisions of the national wage bench. If one looks at what some of the Liberal spokesmen have said on this issue, one sees that there are a great variety of views on whether that is correct or not.
—Now we are off at a tangent again.
—Senator Hill interjects and says that I am off at a tangent again; I am. I have never seen more tangential views than those that have emanated from the Opposition in the last week.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHRISTMAS ISLAND AND COCOS (KEELING) ISLANDS: EFFECTS OF PILOTS DISPUTE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories relates to two of the most isolated communities in my electorate. Has the Government taken measures to maintain air services to the isolated communities of Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands in order to ensure that they have sufficient foodstuffs and at least some essential passenger transport to the mainland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, air services are a lifeblood to the remote communities as Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands. As soon as it became clear that this dispute might last some time, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding, took immediate action to protect the interests of people living in those two communities. The action took the form of three efforts. The first was an approach to the Australian Federation of Airline Pilots for a dispensation to these two communities. In keeping with the miserable attitude of the pilots that has been shown since this dispute began, that request was refused. Secondly, Mr Holding made requests to see what Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) services could be scheduled for the islands. Thirdly, alternative charter arrangements were sought.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to be able to tell Senator Collins that a charter flight has now been arranged for Saturday, 2 September. It will come out of Jakarta and travel through the islands to Perth and return by the same route the next day.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of aeroplane is it?

—An F28-400 aircraft will carry approximately four tonnes of freight into Cocos from Jakarta and will allow up to 80 passengers to travel from the islands into Perth. The return trip will allow approximately 70 passengers to travel to the islands from Perth. Christmas Island also continues to be served by a regular fortnightly air charter to and from Singapore. So there is no urgent freight requirement for Christmas Island.

ANSWER.PARA: Although the extra charter flights to which I have just referred will clear all passenger requirements between the islands and Perth, steps are being taken to ensure that there is at least a fortnightly air service to the islands during the length of the dispute to meet freight and passenger needs. The regular shipping service continues to ensure that the staple requirements for both islands are being provided. The only other point to make is that should an urgent medical evacuation be required, the islands will be entitled to use the Royal Flying Doctor Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer to the answer that the Minister gave at the end of Question Time yesterday concerning the financial arrangements applying to the emergency airlift of passengers stranded by the pilots dispute and, in particular, to the Minister's statement that the airlines are chartering aircraft from the defence forces-an expression that he used again in the answer that he just gave to the Senate. Does the Minister agree that any charter arrangement means payment for full operational cost? While I concede the difficulties in accurately estimating the total cost at this stage, does the Minister not agree that, in the event of a shortfall, this should be picked up by the airlines, not by taxpayers? Does he agree that there should be no suggestion of the airlines making a profit out of the emergency arrangements? Finally, can he advise the Senate whether Hamilton Island flights using military aircraft are continuing and whether other popular tourist destinations are being similarly served?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —On that general question, it is worth repeating what I said yesterday. The arrangements between the airlines and the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) effectively amount to a charter and the airlines are no doubt attempting to cover as many of the air services as they need to. It is a matter for them as to where they are sending them.

ANSWER.PARA: I can give some further information regarding the expenses of the RAAF and the manner of charging the airlines. First of all, the aim of the Government in arranging for the RAAF to assist in maintaining domestic services during the length of the strike has been to ensure that people in isolated destinations, where there is no alternative to air travel, are not particularly disadvantaged. The Government is, therefore, aiming to facilitate the maintenance of air services at normal fares. It is not a matter of the airlines making money out of it; it is a matter of the Government performing a public service and not having people, by reason of where they live, where they find themselves or where they are wanting to go, being disadvantaged during the course of the strike. As a public service, that is what governments ought to be doing. The aircraft are chartered by the airlines at a cost which approximates the normal operating costs of the aircraft.

In the light of those principles, the Government reached agreement with the airlines by which ticketing and seat allocation continues to be handled by the airlines. They retain the proceeds of ticket sales. In return, the airlines are responsible for providing, at their expense, fuel, crew and ground maintenance staff accommodation, meals and transfer costs, ground handling, aircraft cleaning, in-flight rations and minor miscellaneous expenditure. In addition, the airlines are paying an hourly rate to cover spare parts and contractor maintenance. Those rates are: for a Boeing 707, $1,500 an hour; for a HS748, $800 an hour; and for a C130, $970 an hour. These rates are similar to maintenance rates on similar passenger aircraft. Whether they cover the RAAF's actual maintenance expenses will depend on the number of hours flown. We will not know that until the end of the operation. As I said yesterday, if they do not cover the costs, it is the Minister's intention to seek supplementation of the Defence budget to cover that shortfall in the Additional Estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer Senator Button, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, to recent talks on chemical weapons between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) in Geneva. What reports has the Government received with regard to those talks in Geneva and what follow-up steps have been taken by the Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some press publicity in relation to this matter. I think it is instructive to think back a few years when the concerns of the community were very much directed at nuclear disarmament issues. It is important that the chemical weapons issue has now come more to the forefront in negotiations between the major powers. There has been progress in the bilateral talks on chemical weapons between the United States and Soviet negotiators in Geneva. The talks have covered some of the most intractable problems still facing the 40 members of the conference on disarmament as they move towards a comprehensive chemical weapons convention. Agreements reached between the United States and the USSR on issues such as verification procedures, challenge inspections and timetables for destruction of existing chemical weapon stocks will contribute significantly to the multilateral negotiations. A final resolution of the remaining issues must take place in the multilateral forum. However, the chemical weapons convention will be effective only if all nations have confidence in it and are willing to adhere to it.

ANSWER.PARA: As an active participant in the conference on disarmament negotiations for a chemical weapons treaty, Australia is taking practical steps to supplement the conference on disarmament process. Australia will hold a major international conference later this month aimed at fostering a government-industry dialogue on chemical weapons so as to prepare the world's chemical industry for the implementation of the convention and to involve industry in its design and realisation. Australia is also conducting trial inspections of chemical plants to check the effective operation of the proposed verification provisions of the convention and, through the Prime Minister's regional initiative, promoting understanding and acceptance of the proposed convention among our neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Why did the combined armed services spend some $6m in the last financial year to 31 May 1989 on advertising for new recruits when they cannot provide uniforms for existing servicemen? In particular, is the Minister aware that one young man who enlisted in the Army 18 months ago as a 17-year-old grew out of his uniform some eight months ago but is still unable to be supplied with a new uniform by the Army, forcing him to wear his camouflage uniform at all times and to carry a special notice of explanation from his superior officer? As I understand that this case is but one of numerous examples, will the Government ensure that the Army has adequate funds to properly outfit and care for existing personnel before vast sums of taxpayers' money are spent on increasing its numbers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly the Government's intention that all Defence Force personnel should grow in the job. I thank Senator Chapman for confirming that that is in fact occurring. I am not aware of the case to which the honourable senator referred. It would seem a bit odd and indeed inappropriate if we did not provide uniforms for our young soldiers. If we are not doing so I will make it my business to do something about it immediately.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of new negotiations between the Queensland Government and the coalmining industry over adjustments to coal rail freight rates in Queensland? Have there been any substantial breakthroughs in those negotiations and will the industry receive any real benefits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome Senator Burns's question. I suspect that Senator Parer, who sits opposite, may be able to support many of the remarks I am about to make in answering it. The facts on coal rail freights in Queensland are as follows. No new coalmine has been opened in Queensland in the last five years. Many critics in the industry say that one of the reasons for that is the pernicious form of rail freight tax levied by that State Government. An analysis that I have seen shows that it costs more to send one tonne of coal 200 kilometres in Queensland by rail than it does to ship it anywhere in the world. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics showed in its March publication Agricultural and Resources Quarterly that the total freight cost in open-cut coalmines in Australia is 24 per cent. One would say that it is probably higher than that in Queensland. The International Energy Agency of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development criticised the level of the pernicious hidden tax in Queensland. In the post-Fitzgerald report scene in Queensland there has been no move to open up the issue on this form of hidden tax for public scrutiny, although the report of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct recommended that there be open government. The industry's ability to pay the tax is also questionable. Just this Wednesday Mount Isa Mines' coal division announced a loss of $85m for its 1988-89 trading year, which follows a $66m loss for its coal division in 1987-88.

ANSWER.PARA: The total freight surcharge has been estimated as being $399m in 1986-87 and $376m in 1987-88, which is quite a levy on an export industry. The freight charge is a regressive tax in that sense. Against that background, this week the Ahern Government announced changes to its freight levels. There have been consultations with the industry. One can take a cynical view and say that in the rampant expectation of an election in Queensland this is a manoeuvre in the political scene to try to kill what is a major domestic issue in Queensland. Has it succeeded? The Ahern Government talked to the industry and announced a new formula. However, the formula applies only to new mines and major extensions to existing mines. So there is total discrimination against existing producers and there will be no relief for those producers. It has done nothing about the provision for increasing freight charges if coal prices increase. I have received many representations from industry to the effect that it is very unhappy about this. Senator Burns has obviously touched on a very sensitive question in Queensland. He has identified a government in panic. We are not quite sure whether Ahern will be leader next week or next month. I hope that Senator Parer will be as outspoken on this matter as are some of his industry supporters within the National Party and his party room.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate also in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister, the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask: Is the Government aware how many applications the airlines have received in response to their advertisements for air crew? Does the Government have any breakdown of the national origins of the applicants? Is it a fact that a large number of those who have applied are Argentinean citizens?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. The building industry, together with the motor vehicle industry, is one of the biggest areas for consumer complaint in Australia. What action can the Government take to try to protect young home buyers from some of the shady dealers in the industry? I refer particularly to the practice in New South Wales where young home buyers sign for a fixed price contract only to find the builder uses an escape clause to add $10,000 to $20,000 to the price of a house.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Childs is correct in saying that the building industry is one of the two areas of major complaint. It can be quite rightly called `a rich source of complaints by consumers'. The honourable senator was also right in isolating home buyers as being a particularly vulnerable part of the industry. The most common sources of complaints are in one of two areas: firstly, either harassment or coercion into buying a property, and secondly-it is the activity which Senator Child mentioned-the use of a so-called fixed price contract which by unnecessary delay is evaded by the builder involved and thereafter the home buyer has to pay extra costs because of the expiry of the term to which the fixed price applies. It is fair to say that this sort of activity does not extend across the building industry, but it is also fair to say that it applies in more than one State. It has occurred not only in New South Wales, but also in Western Australia-there was a notorious participant there-and Queensland. I have been concerned about it and I spent some time in Queensland a couple of months ago. In one part of Brisbane a particular builder was fleecing, ripping off, young home buyers in this way.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has responded through the Trade Practices Commission which has moved quite swiftly to try to protect home buyers and to make sure that they get their houses at fair prices. It should be recognised that the direct implication of this is that we level out the playing field in the building industry, in that builders can compete fairly, instead of one particular builder having an advantage because of such devious behaviour. In particular, and leading up to a case that was settled yesterday, the Trade Practices Commission took legal action against a New South Wales company, Kimberley Homes Pty Ltd. That action resulted in a settlement without admission, but a settlement nonetheless, with four families being paid $35,000 in compensation for damages they incurred because of this sort of activity.

This was in fact a precedent-setting case. It was one taken in accordance with the commitment of the Trade Practices Commission to give priority to the use of the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act. It was also an unprecedented one in that it was once again the use of representative actions-the limited source of representative actions-that applied under the Trade Practices Act. As I said, the couples involved have been compensated to the extent of $35,000. It is a major victory for first home buyers, in particular. It brings honesty into the marketplace. The Trade Practices Commission has already given an indication that it will enforce these results not only with further action against Kimberley Homes, but also with an education campaign through this part of the building industry as well as through other industries to alert them to the implications of this part of the Trade Practices Act. It is a clear demonstration that the Government is quite serious about achieving fairness in the marketplace, fairness to consumers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Put out a press release, will you?
—That is something Senator Alston would not know about-and fairness to business.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. What is being done through the youth social justice strategy announced in the Budget to improve the access to employment, education and training of young people who are disadvantaged because they face barriers such as lack of training or experience or, particularly in the case of young people in rural areas, living a long way from possible places of employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Youth unemployment has declined quite substantially in recent years. In spite of that, the incidence of long-term unemployment, especially on a regional basis-I know that Senator Zakharov was particularly interested in the rural youth unemployed-remains a problem. Accordingly, the Commonwealth will allocate nearly $26m over the next four years to improve training and unemployment support for the most disadvantaged. ANSWER.PARA: Specifically, we will introduce the joint Social Security and Commonwealth Employment Service contract arrangement for all job search allowance recipients after 12 months continuous registration with the CES, the objective being to improve the quality of information available to long-term unemployed people on a range of issues-labour market training, entry assistance and so on. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Boswell proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage caused to Australian small business by the anti-business policies of the Hawke Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Opposition has raised as a matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The damage caused to Australian small business by the anti-business policies of the Hawke Government.

We have done this because over the past seven years we have seen this Government completely ignore the importance of small business. It is becoming increasingly obvious to us that the Government is becoming more and more intolerant to the small business community as a whole. Only yesterday we saw an attack-I can only describe it as a vendetta-on the pharmacies of Australia. We have seen taxes increase by 105 per cent since the Federal election held seven years ago. We have seen sales tax increase and we have seen the industrial relations policies of the Government impacting on small business. In all, the Government's policies have been a total disaster.

That is probably understandable. I went to the Parliamentary Library today to find out details of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) platform on small business. The ALP believes small business is worthy of three paragraphs in its platform. That is all the response it could muster to small business. It reads in part:

Labor recognises the importance of maintaining a strong, viable and diverse small business sector. It accounts for 95% of all businesses in Australia, over 50% of private sector employment and 40% of value-added.

That is rhetoric; it does not do much for small business. When Senator Button responded to the Coles-Myer amalgamation which was to give those two companies tremendous market clout, he said that it was not in the best interests of Australian commerce. That is all Senator Button did regarding that amalgamation. The third point in the Labor platform on small business reads:

Improve the co-ordination between business regulatory agencies to minimise the administrative complexity and cost for industry of government regulations and procedures, particularly for small businesses.

The total response to more than 750,000 small businesses in Australia comprises three paragraphs of Labor Party policy. The small business sector employs 52 per cent of the private sector employees. There are over 50,000 small manufacturers and over 80,000 small businesses involved in providing services. These businesses are the major source of tax collections-sales tax, pay as you earn tax and child support payments.

I believe the Government is treating the small business area as a means through which to raise tax revenue. The Government is not giving sufficient recognition to the small business sector. Small business does not have the influence with this Government consistent with its importance. Apart from one lone voice on the Economic Planning Advisory Council there is very little representation on any Government instrumentality, council or organisation that represents the voice of small business. Big business is represented by the Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry. But the voice of small business is not very often heard. Apart from Peter Boyle, Director of the Australian Small Business Association, and Rob Bastian, from the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, there are very few organisations that represent this terribly important sector-small business. That needs to be remedied because the small business voice is not coming through to this Government. I want to refer to the attack on the pharmacies.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the attack on the tourism industry.

—And the tourism industry. I will move through some of the other areas in which this Government has been totally negligent in its response to small business. As I said in my opening remarks, this Government seems to have some sort of vendetta against the pharmacists and the chemists of Australia. This vendetta has been running since January 1988, when the Government lowered the wholesale margin by 5 per cent for the chemists and the pharmacists.

SPEECH.PARA: In August 1988, the Government doubled the number of items per prescription and effectively halved the handling fee. Some expensive but essential drugs were then put on a hit list and doctors had to seek approval from the Department of Community Services and Health before prescribing the drugs and allowing patients access to these drugs. Due to public pressure and extensive complaints by a number of groups, particularly the pensioners, this was reversed. In January 1989 the Government attempted to further reduce the prescription fee to below $2.64. That has put pressure on the pharmacists.

No-one could have expected that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal's report would have been accepted by the Government, but the Government accepted the recommendations to reduce the pharmacists' dispensing payments by $1.05 per item and abolish the pharmacists' 25 per cent mark-up. I do not know how any government can support a recommendation such as that. How can any business work without some type of mark-up? There are 5,000 chemists in Australia and, on present indications, about 1,000 of those would become bankrupt were the Government to implement those recommendations.

What is the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Barry Jones, doing about that? I recognise Barry Jones's capabilities in many areas. He may be the Minister for Science, but he certainly has no expertise in small business. I would have thought that the Australian Labor Party could have come up with someone that could have given some representation to small business. We never hear Barry Jones speaking up on how government legislation will affect small business, what it will do to small business and whether small business has a capacity to pay. In effect, the Labor Party does not have anyone within its ranks that can truly represent small business. I do not believe there is one person in the Labor Party that has ever been in small business. I could be corrected but, as I look around the Senate today-there are not too many people here from the Labor side; there are many National Party members and many Liberal Party members-there is not one person on the other side who could represent small business. There is no-one here to listen to the pleadings of small business. The Minister, Mr Jones, should be more responsible for the actions affecting small business that this Government has taken.

What has small business had to put up with? We have seen cripplingly high interest rates. They are supposed to slow the economy down, but as Senator Stone quite correctly pointed out, it is a very vague and hollow way to slow down an economy because once it slows down where does one go from there? The present high interest rates are impacting directly on the building industry. Retail sales figures and figures for new car registrations have shown that consumer demand is still strong. But there is plenty of evidence to suggest that the present high interest rates are bankrupting small businesses. The Hawke Government has promised consistently and constantly that interest rates will come down. Interest rates for housing loans are now 18 per cent. In the small business community they can be as high as 23 per cent. What small business can afford to pay 23 per cent interest rates? Very few small businesses have the capacity to earn 23 per cent profit, let alone pay interest rates of 23 per cent. A string of bankruptcies is occurring throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has just put out a video on bankruptcy to advise people how to go about their business.
—Senator Stone says that the Government's answer to bankruptcies is to put out a video to handle the people who have gone bankrupt.
—Do-it-yourself bankruptcy.

—It is a do-it-yourself bankruptcy kit. I would prefer to look at the symptoms rather than the cause, but the bankruptcy video is an example of the completely convoluted way the Labor Party handles these types of issues. In 1982-83, there were 6,000 bankruptcies in Australia. That is not a good figure; it is not a figure to be proud of. In the Government's six years in office, the number of bankruptcies has gone up by 56 per cent. The major factor has been high interest rates.
—Wait until you see this year's.

—This year's figures will be a total disaster. Of course, when one sits in this place and looks at the frontbench one sees the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who is a lawyer; Senator Cooney, who is a barrister; and trade union officials. They do not know what it does to people to have their businesses crash around them. The Government does not know what it does to their families, and their self-confidence. The Government is leaving a trail of disasters around Australia with its high interest rates and it does not care about the destruction it is causing: families splitting up, the destruction of people's self-confidence. Those are the sorts of things that one must consider.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Barry Jones, understands it. I am certain that no-one in the Senate understands the feelings of small business owners. Small business people get out there, on a very low capital base, and try to achieve. They are Australia's greatest battlers. I know; I have been one of them. For 16 years I worked my own small business. Under Labor, if one wants a small business one buys a big business and watches it get smaller. That is the only thing the Government can say it knows about small business-buy a big business and under Labor it will get smaller. The alternative to that is that one goes bankrupt, as the figures have indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you get the video.

—Of course, there is the great light at the end of the tunnel, the light on the hill. When one goes bankrupt one applies to the Government and gets its bankruptcy video. That gives you great satisfaction of knowing that the Government is really looking after your interests.
—One of your ideas, Tatey?
—Whose idea was that?
—It was Senator Bolkus's idea.

—It sounds like one of Senator Bolkus's ideas. Madam Acting Deputy President, I know that you understand small business because your husband was involved in small business before he entered politics. Let us consider the progressive taxation take from 1983 to 1990. This Government has extracted-pulled out like teeth-a 105 per cent tax increase. Total Commonwealth tax revenue has increased by 105 per cent. Total individual tax has gone up by 107 per cent. The Medicare levy has gone up; company tax has gone up by 162 per cent; sales tax has gone up by 156 per cent; Customs import duty has gone up by 73.9 per cent; and petroleum excise has gone up by 186.3 per cent. Yet this Government tells us that it has a Budget surplus. It claims that it is a wonderful economic manager and that it has a $9 billion surplus. Of course, it will have a $9 billion Budget surplus if it increases everything from sales tax and fuel excise to Customs duty and the Medicare levy. Every tax has increased, and the major impact has been felt by small business. The Government does not realise that when it increases petroleum excise by 186.3 per cent it is the small business sales representatives that pay most of it, as they travel in their cars to sell their products. These taxes are impacting on small business. It is no wonder that bankruptcies have increased by 56 per cent. I say to the Minister for Justice, who is a barrister and solicitor-and probably a very good one-that his Government needs to understand what it is doing to small business.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has introduced a capital gains tax which has impacted on small businesses. Many small business want to expand by buying out other businesses. Farmers may wish to move from a smaller property to a bigger property. They have to pay a capital gains tax every time there is a roll-over. In the past, many small businesses, particularly newsagents, could afford to take a holiday only after they had sold their business. Many small business people cannot even afford to do that any more because of the capital gains tax.

This Government's tax regime has been a disaster for all small businesses. The capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and other taxes have impacted heavily on small business. Small businesses account for much of Australia's wealth. They provide many jobs and much of the tax revenue, yet they do not receive a fair go from this Government. This Government treats the small business sector as an area from which to gather tax. This Government thinks in terms of how much sales tax it can collect from that sector, how much pay as you earn tax or capital gains tax small businesses can pay. Small businesses are the greatest milch cows that this Government has, yet it does not give small businesses one voice. It does not give small business any consideration. This Government does not have a Minister who can adequately represent the interest of small business in Cabinet, who can look at the impact of Government policy on small business. This Government's total contribution to the small business area comprises three paragraphs in its policy document. It is a shocking indictment of any government that an area which provides 52 per cent of employment, and probably most of Australia's taxation revenue, receives three paragraphs in the Australian Labor Party's policy document.

It is not good enough for the small business community. It is not good enough for Australia. I hope that this Government will look at the problem in its next six months in office, although I do not suppose there is much time left for it to do anything for small business. I suppose that the message that I can give to small business is, `Hang on by your fingernails. Help is coming. The coalition will be in government in six months time'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard another very great speech from Senator Boswell. One thing that can be said about Senator Boswell, and I say it with all sincerity, is that if there is one thing that is passionate to his heart it is small business. Perhaps he is not so passionate in the defence of big business; small business is his go. Big business is left to the Australian Labor Party. It has been left to the Labor Party, because we have done very well by it. We have also done very well by small business.
—Look after your rich mates.

—That is right. We have mates in big business-big mates-and we also have mates in small business. We have mates because what we do is help the whole community. Whether they be workers, employers, big business or small business, farmers, consumers or ordinary citizens, we do well by them all and they do very well by us. We do very well by them because they vote us into office, which is proper. They do well by us because, their having voted us into office, we give them the best available for the community. Let me make it clear that what is best available for the community at the moment is not as good as it might be. There are hard economic times upon us. There are difficulties for all sections of the community. But in so far as anything can be done within those parameters, the best people to do it are the members of the present Government and that will be vindicated again within the next few months.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell says that taxes have increased. The reality is that under this Government tax rates have been reduced. Small business has benefited by that, and benefited mightily. It is worth going through the tax rates. One can earn up to $5,100 without any tax being imposed at all. From $5,100 to $17,650 the tax rate is 21 per cent; from $17,650 to $26,000 it is 29 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the 150 per cent rise in sales tax, for example?

—I will come back to that. From $26,000 to $35,000 the tax rate is 39 per cent; from $35,000 to $50,000, 47 per cent; and over $50,000, 49 per cent, but that will be reduced on 1 January next year to 47 per cent. I do not expect actual applause from the other side but I think, deep in the hearts of honourable senators opposite-including Senator Stone-there is admiration for what this Government has done in terms of the tax rates.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell has spoken about capital gains tax. He says it has impacted on business and farmers because, in the process of buying and selling property, they have to pay capital gains tax if they sell for more than they paid, at an indexed value. That argument is always put up, no matter what tax is imposed. People who earn money have to pay tax. All that means is that for the country to run, for there to be an economic policy, there has to be some collection of moneys from the community, and it is a question of where that collection ought to fall. I am sure that Senator Boswell would not say that if capital gains tax were removed the rates of income tax should be raised. I am sure that is not his position. It is all very well to come into the chamber day in and day out-it sometimes leads to good debate-and say that there are problems. Of course there are problems in the economy. The real question is: What are the answers? It is easy enough for anybody to come along and say that there is a problem. It is easy to see where the difficulties are. But the real skill-this skill has been shown by the great Treasurer, Paul Keating, and the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, whom we all admire-is to devise an answer to these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you stand there and say these things?

—We on this side of the chamber say, `True enough, there are the problems'. The Opposition has diagnosed those problems and has said, `Here are the problems'. The greatness of this Government is that it has the answers. As time goes by into the 1990s this economy will be seen to run very well because of the results of the policies that have been pursued through the 1980s.
—Into the 1990s.
—Into the 1990s, yes.
—Your balance of payments or current account is going badly. You have the country in debt.
—Senator Cooney is making the speech, Senator Brownhill.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I thank you for the protection that you offer me in this chamber against the very deadly interjections made from the other side. Senator Boswell has talked about crippling interest rates. There is no doubt that interest rates are high and that they will continue to be high into the foreseeable future. What is happening-this statement has been made again and again-and what is quite real is that the economy is overheating. As the Treasurer has said, it is bubbling up as bubbles might rise in a champagne glass, and something has to be done about it. The policy that has been pursued here is both a fiscal and a monetary policy. The monetary policy is one of high interest rates, and it has been stated again and again that it is dampening down the economy, perhaps not as fast as it should. If that were not the case, things would be more disastrous.
—It is killing the economy.

—Senator Brownhill says that it is killing the economy. I have a quote from one of the papers which says that there is just too much high investment going on and that it has to be slowed down. If it is killing the economy, the reality of the matter is that that has not been reflected. Senator Boswell has said that the pharmacies are an illustration of how badly this Government has dealt with small business. It is true that there has been a proposed change to the rate at which chemists are to be remunerated. Nobody likes the remuneration reduced; in fact, the work force has had its remuneration reduced considerably over the last few years and discussions are still taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell says-I can understand his keenness and desperation almost to help the small business person, and in this particular case the pharmacist-`Let us ignore what the Tribunal has said. There is no need for the Government to accept what the Tribunal has said'. The great difficulty about that argument is: if we ignore the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, what other tribunals do we ignore? Do we ignore the Industrial Relations Tribunal, and do we start ignoring the courts themselves?

The real problem in all this is that the more we ignore the tribunals, the courts and the institutions that have been set up to carry out particular functions, the greater threat there is to the structures of society and the way it works. I quote from an article by Milton Cockburn headed `Pharmacist fee cut a Labor headache' which appears in today's Sydney Morning Herald:

When the Fraser Government established the tribunal the then Minister for Health, Mr Michael MacKellar, promised it would `remove from the political arena the level of fees paid to chemists for the dispensing of pharmaceutical benefits'. That has proved to be a naive promise with Opposition MPs falling over themselves in the past few days to attack the tribunal's decision and the Democrats threatening legislation to overturn the decision.

What we take from that is this: there is a recognition, at least by Milton Cockburn, of the particular problems that are faced not only by this Government but also by the community and by other governments that if we are going to have a tribunal we cannot accept some things and not accept other things. That is the real difficulty. I would like honourable senators who will speak after me to explain how we overcome that problem. This is a great illustration of the sorts of debates that we have in this chamber again and again. People come to us and say `we have a problem'. In this case there is a problem with the chemists, they say they are not getting enough. We may or may not agree with that, but say for the purpose of the argument that we agree. The pharmacists go to the Tribunal to put their case and the Tribunal says, `Look, X is the amount of money you are going to get'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They put their case to the Tribunal and it took more away.
—Senator Boswell is absolutely right. The real question is: What do we do about that? Do we ignore this body?
—Sack the Tribunal.

—Senator Watson says that if we do not like the Tribunal's decision-this Tribunal was set up by the Fraser Government with high praise from Mr MacKellar, a great Minister for Health, a man with great vision-we should throw it out. We should just ignore what the Tribunal says. What do we do next week? If we do not like a decision on wages that is brought down by the Industrial Relations Commission we should ignore it.
—At least it has expertise in the area; that is the difference.

—I ask the honourable senator to follow the argument through. The next week we go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which gives a decision about social security payments, but because we do not like the decision we ignore it. The next week a decision under the Trade Practices Act is made by the Federal Court and we say, `We don't like your decision on sections 45d and 45e, so we are going to ignore it'. We get to the point where the High Court of Australia makes a decision and we say, `We really didn't expect you to give that decision. We are pretty disappointed with it. We will just legislate our way out of this because we don't like it'. The problem is that the whole system breaks down because we say, `We think that a particular group has not been properly rewarded'. Because the official tribunal has said something different-and there is no suggestion that the Tribunal did not act honestly-we say, `The decision has to be ignored and we have to introduce legislation to overcome it. We don't like it. We'll ignore it'. If that is the approach we take, then the difficulty will lie not only with small businesses but with the very structures on which our society operates.

SPEECH.PARA: It is said that this Government ignores small business. It is said that Barry Jones does not press his case as well as he should. A lot of this is in the eyes of the perceiver. The perceiver does not look often enough at what is done for small business or other sections. Let us look, for example, at a body that this Government encourages-the Business Regulation Review Unit-as an illustration of what can be done. The Government has issued an invitation to anybody in small business who thinks that the regulations imposed upon his business or the class of business that he is in are unfair to take a complaint to or make a request of this body. The Business Regulation Review Unit has an information paper No. 15 entitled Review of Business Regulations-Major Changes in Business Regulation during 1988. This information paper, which was published in July 1989, sets out the procedure by which that can be done.

It has been said that the taxation system has gone against small business. It is true that the amount of money owed, not only by small business but also by business generally, now has to be paid earlier than it otherwise would have been paid. It does not have to be paid until a period has passed after it has been earned, which is different--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteen days.
—Did you get your fees in 15 days?
—In the old days solicitors were never paid for years at a time. Senator Boswell is tempting me to get fairly passionate about that. In any event, the fact is that small business is still better off.
—You did not pay your tax on it.

—That is true. I wish to make one point before I run out of time: a small business which is run by, say, a family and which is not incorporated has had to pay taxes as it earns. Only companies have been affected by these changes in the past so that they could pay due taxes a year or up to two years after earning their income. That has been changed. Honourable senators opposite might think it is fairer that people running a business, no matter who they are-a company, a man and a woman, or a family-be on equal footing. This change has put everybody in small business, whether a company or a family concern not incorporated, on an equal footing.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing this Government has done for small business people is to offer them better corporate law than has been available up until now.
