It has introduced concepts such as the close corporations legislation so that there is one law to guide companies throughout Australia. In fact, the more we think about it, the more it becomes apparent that this Government has done many things for small business. This Budget has made things fairer. Look at what it has done now. It has introduced deductions for the cost of tax advice--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was my recommendation.
—Senator Watson brought it to your attention.
—And he needs great praise for that. I publicly congratulate Senator Watson.
—Steady on.

—I think his idea is a great one. This Government is a very flexible government; we listen to what is put forward. What Senator Watson has said illustrates what I have been saying in my speech. If anybody brings forth a fair proposition, we will take it on board. We have in place mechanisms which allow small business to do just that.
—You will be just as fair to the pharmacists, will you?

—Of course, we will be fair to the pharmacists. I hope that the honourable senator is not suggesting that a duly constituted body that was set up by the coalition Government in the 1970s is not a fair body. Even when it is fair, this Government is prepared to look at making what the chemists get even fairer. The new superannuation benefits that have been put forward in this latest Budget are another illustration of how this Government has done a great deal for small business. In Senator Boswell's passion for small business his emotions have overcome his judgment on this one occasion.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support the essential proposition before the chamber-namely, that it is indeed a tragedy that small business in this country has been decimated by governments. That is the situation in Australia today. I do not think, however, that the Australian Democrats are prepared to accept the precise wording of the matter of public importance that has been brought before the chamber by Senator Boswell-namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The damage caused to Australian small business by the anti-business policies of the Hawke Government.

In reality the tragedy has been the damage caused to Australian small business by the big business policies of successive governments. It is not only the Hawke Government that has let down small business. Small business has been let down over decades in this nation by successive governments, and in the letting down of small business big business has been sustained.

Some businesses have thrived in Australia in recent times. We all know of the giants that have emerged, the people who have come to this country and have thrived, presumably through a stage of small business, into the stage of big business where they have been favoured and lived in a climate that has sustained, savoured, spoilt and nurtured them to the point where they have become greedy. Some of them are now beginning to collapse and are moving into a stage of demise. When this proposition was tabled here today and we were advised of it my colleague Senator Macklin was prompted to say that it is possible to be successful in small business in Australia today. The successful small businesses are those that have been big and in their period of demise, if they are shrewd enough, can hang in for a short period when they are successful before finally being sent packing by a palling government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly what I said.

—I am agreeing with Senator Boswell that there is a tragic situation in Australia today. We acknowledge what he has already cited, that small business is an area that has been too long neglected by successive Federal and State governments. We acknowledge the fact that more than half of our private sector is made up of businesses which employ fewer than 100 people. This is obviously an immensely important group of people but they have been, and probably still are, largely uncoordinated. They do not pull their power together as an effective lobby in this country. Despite the genuine attempts of the Australian Small Business Association (ASBA) and the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia (COSBOA), small business has not become the potent lobby that it should be in this country. We call ourselves a free enterprise economy, a free enterprise nation, which the Australian Democrats endorse as the fundamental posture and structure of our economy. The essence of such a free enterprise economy is effective small business, yet successive government after government has decimated that essential ingredient of the free enterprise economy.

SPEECH.PARA: If all small businesses, including farmers, could gather under one umbrella organisation they would make the most powerful lobby in the nation, but for some reason or other they have not been able to get their act together. The reason is probably that most of them work for 70 or 80 hours a week and barely manage to get a substantial living together. They simply do not have the time to assemble the clout to render effective what should be one of the most powerful lobbies in the nation. The current Labor Government has not seen small business as particularly high on its list of priorities. Neither did the Fraser Government, for that matter. The coalition supports big business. The Australian Labor Party supposedly is the party of trade unions, although lately it has been more the party of big businesses as well. Neither has done a great deal to sustain the small business sector in this country over the last two or three decades.

In the light of this, it is sad to reflect that several of the small business umbrella organisations appear to have been hijacked by the New Right. It is a move which has brought them no advantage whatsoever. In the discussion of the Australian Democrats with small businesses, they have said that if they are going to have political muscle they have got to be prepared to move their vote around. In fact, they have stayed in a constant allegiance to the right in politics, and that has delivered to them very little indeed.

Small business is the key to decentralising economic power. For this reason, the Australian Democrats believe that they should be supported as much as possible. That will probably not be a popular view among those who believe in cronyism and the beneficent power of monopolies. We emphasise that small businesses are the key to the decentralisation of power in this nation, power which is concentrated increasingly in the hands of fewer and fewer enterprises. High interest rates, which appear currently to be the only economic tool being used by the Government, are putting immense pressure on small business. They are decimating small business.

In an article in the most recent edition of the news bulletin of the Australian Small Business Association, ASBA News, Brian Buckley suggested that the Treasurer should be replaced by the Minister for Finance and their two departments merged. The most interesting thing about the suggestion is the reasons he gives for it. He sees some qualities in the Finance Minister which, presumably, would be advantageous to small business. He says:

Walsh is as tough as Keating, fights even dirtier, is extremely sceptical of official advice, understands the broad economic issues, has no special mates in the union movement and is a wheat farmer (i.e. an exporter).

The Labor, Liberal and National parties all agree that deregulation is an excellent thing and that the sooner it is done the better, but none of them has supported my private members Bill which focuses specifically on the challenges of deregulating in order to free up the climate in which small businesses attempt to operate. On the issue of sales tax, in 1981 my predecessor as Australian Democrat senator for New South Wales, Colin Mason, gave notice of the following motion:
That the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should extend the prescribed period of time currently allowed to pay sales tax from 21 days to 60 days . . .

The notice of motion elaborated on that, yet it has not received the support of the Opposition and, therefore, has never been successfully brought forward. Nothing has changed. Small businesses and their umbrella organisations are still crying out for this basic relief, and for the same reasons. The Liberal-National Party Government refused to listen when it was in power and had the power to do something about it, and the Labor Government has refused to listen ever since.

Before the last Federal election, COSBOA produced a matrix in which it cited what it believed to be the 13 critical factors which were bringing down small business in this nation, and it sought the response of the political parties before the election. On its matrix, under the heading of `The Government', is simply written `Polite refusal'. In other words, the Government refused to respond to a questionnaire about the 13 most critical factors relating to small business. It is interesting that it adjudged the policies of the Australian Democrats to be the most generous in terms of the requirements of people in small business.

One field which should be of particular use to small business is that of research and development, which has been grossly neglected for decades in this country. Governments and businesses of all sizes should be required to put far more resources into this vital field. We must encourage scientific research, product and service development and scholarship.

I have devoted a great deal of attention to banks. Banks are devastating small business in this country. That process of devastation was brought into effect in 1984 when the present Government deregulated the banking system. Traditionally, small business people have looked to banks as being their primary ally but today, in the context of deregulation, banks are literally devastating small business people. Irrespective of whether they are small farmers or your typical small business in an urban area, their traditional ally has left them high and dry in the interests of what it describes as super profits. Six months ago I suggested that this country's banking system be placed before the appropriate Senate committee for inquiry, but my proposition was defeated by the combined vote of the Government and the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a ludicrous proposal.

—It was not a ludicrous proposal. If Senator Stone asked the community now what it thinks about a proposal to refer banking to a Senate committee for inquiry, I would defy him to bring back a legitimate answer that it thinks it is a ludicrous proposal. The community thinks that such an inquiry is absolutely essential. Banking is likely to become the issue of the decade: it is on the rise. The proposition that banking be referred to a Senate committee will come before the Senate again in a few weeks time because I will bring it back. The climate in the community has changed dramatically and I believe that the political climate has changed sufficiently for both the Government and the Opposition to be forced to seriously reconsider the issue.
—Why don't you stop playing politics on this issue and stop giving people false hopes?

—When the issue was brought before the chamber last time we analysed, as the business community did, Senator Stone's responses. I am aware of some of the reactions because they have been communicated to me in terms just as strong as those communicated to Senator Stone. They were rejected out of hand. The proposition of a Senate inquiry into banking falls very well with the business community and the community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: On four occasions this week we have considered the pilots dispute. That dispute has been cited as having a devastating impact on the business community. In a question to Senator Richardson today I implied-and I think that he accepted the fact-that it has the potential to have a devastating effect on the morale of pilots in the defence forces. Small business people are vulnerable in numerous ways. They are particularly vulnerable to government policies which are designed essentially to favour big business.

In 1984 we cited a predatory situation in which big business picks off small businesses one after the other, often with the assistance of bankers. The big business predators, in conjunction with the banks, go around like devastated animals and live off small business. When we attempted, with the support of COSBOA and ASBA, to introduce a private member's Bill to rectify that predatory situation, the Bill was defeated by the combined vote of the Government and the Opposition. Sadly, over and over again, legislation or amendment to legislation in favour of small business is defeated by the combined vote of both Government and Opposition. We support the proposition before the chamber that it is a matter of public importance that small business has been devastated, but we argue that it has been devastated by successive Federal and State governments. It is certainly worthy of this chamber's attention and it will, hopefully, begin to acknowledge the extraordinary place of small business in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of the Senate, I will repeat the terms of the matter of public importance introduced today by Senator Boswell, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The damage caused to Australian small business by the anti-business policies of the Hawke Government.

I refer briefly to a couple of matters put forward by an honourable senator from Victoria, Senator Cooney. In the 20 minutes or half an hour that he spoke, he did not state at any stage what help this Government had been to small business, although he did admit that my colleague from Tasmania, Senator Watson, has been very good to small business by finding a loophole in the small business system. However, the honourable senator did say that the Government had the answers. If the Government has the answers, I would like to know what answers it has to the pilots dispute that is on at the moment. I would like to know what answers the Government has with respect to bankruptcies. Senator Stone mentioned that Senator Bolkus has put out a video on bankruptcy. I suppose that will really help to ease the pain of those people who see their houses being sold up and their cars going down the road! I am sure that will be a great help.

I just wonder what answers the Government has to those pharmacists who will be forced to close their doors because of the recommendations from the Remuneration Tribunal that Senator Cooney spent so much time defending. I note he mentioned the fact that the Australian Democrats are also concerned about the matter. With respect to the pharmacists, I ask who else in the history of this nation-certainly not any union worker-would accept the fact that having increased their productivity by 5 per cent, their incomes are to be reduced by between $25,000 and $40,000 a year. I can just imagine the sorts of disputes we would see around this country if unionised workers were asked to accept such a situation. They would make this pilots dispute seem like a boy scouts picnic.

The reason we brought this matter forward is the drastic plight that is facing small business in Australia today. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-who is the man responsible for the Federal Budget-over the years have developed a very good reputation as friends of the rich and powerful. I was very interested to hear even Senator Cooney refer to that; he almost supported it. This could be the reason that the Government has lost sight of small business. It is simply too busy looking after its big mates. Regardless of that and regardless of the comments made by Senator McLean that big business is getting all the runs on the board, it is interesting to note that the 800,000 small businesses in Australia employ around 70 per cent of the work force, a not insignificant figure. So if we have a healthy and prosperous small business sector in Australia, our economy will improve. Unfortunately, the Government has blatantly ignored the pleas for assistance from small business.

As Senator Boswell said earlier, the Government remains the highest taxing government since the last world war. Inflation is rampant and petrol excise, a cost borne by all small businesses, has skyrocketed from 6.15c just six years ago to 22.39c in February of this year. The total expected Budget surplus for 1989-90 is $9.6 billion. I had to wonder what small business people thought today when they heard the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) gloating about the huge Budget surplus. The Government has a Budget surplus all right-but it has accrued at the expense of the taxpayers and the small business community of this country. The Government has increased sales taxes and indexed them to the consumer price index, thereby ensuring that there will be rises, with inflation, twice a year. Our gross current account deficit has blown out of all proportion. The Government, to its shame, has succeeded in increasing our debt level by over $100 billion in just six years. Amidst all this crisis it has used but one tool to try to control the situation-that is, interest rates. If high interest rates ever hit anybody, they hit small business, which employs the majority of the work force, as I said earlier. High interest rates mean that small businesses face increasing problems just to stay in business. Fewer small businesses mean less employment, and less employment in small business means that more people will be receiving unemployment benefits instead of paying a reasonable tax which this country needs to survive.

If there is any conclusion to be drawn, surely it is that this Government favours big business, union power and a centralised government. It is not a government which is prepared to help the Aussie worker who has helped to develop our country over the years. Would it be a caring government that has refused to bite the bullet and make our shipping lines and wharves more effective? As an example, just the other day I heard it stated that clay pottery can be transported from England to Tasmania more cheaply than from Melbourne. This is a ridiculous situation, and it has continued during the entire period that this Government has been in office. The Government has only paid lip service to the real action while the small business operators have paid the price-a price which is hampering their cost effectiveness compared to overseas competitors and hence their ability to expand.

Only yesterday we heard the news of the biggest slump in housing approvals for more than a decade. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures indicate that approvals for dwelling units fell by a massive 18.2 per cent on a seasonally adjusted basis, from 14,831 in June to 12,134 in July-the biggest monthly drop for over 12 years. A little over a year ago approvals stood at 15,299. The number of private sector houses approved fell by 13.3 per cent to 8,136 in July. That figure is the lowest monthly figure since August 1987. In unadjusted terms, dwelling unit approvals plunged 21.8 per cent. It is quite clear-it has been admitted-what has caused this drop in approvals: record interest rates. They are hitting the mortgage belt. As they bite hard and hit the mortgage belt a lot of other people will suffer. I refer to the people down the track who do all the work: the builders, the bricklayers, the tilers-all those people involved in the building industry, all those small businesses. We only have to read what Mr John Murray, the Executive Director of the Construction and Housing Association of Australia, said recently. He summed up the situation when he said:
It is totally inappropriate for interest rate sensitive sectors to become the battering ram for macroeconomic policy.

The Executive Director of the Housing Industry Association, Dr Silberberg, also commented, saying that to force the housing industry into a recession does not make sense. Not only does it not make sense from an economic point of view but it also does not make sense when we look at the hundreds of small businesses around Australia which are going to feel the weight of this interest rate saga. It will be the plumbers, contractors, carpenters and carpet layers and others involved in small businesses that will suffer because of these ridiculously high interest rates forced on us by this Government.

We can look at the real estate industry. I am aware of a company on the north-west coast of Tasmania which, prior to this interest rate hike, was selling six houses a week. Now it would be lucky to sell six houses a month. They are feeling the pinch just like other small businesses around the country.

I turn to another matter which affects small business-something else this Government supports strongly-that is, the centralised wage fixing system. It has been widely acknowledged that one of the key problems facing small business today is the inadequacy of the centralised wage fixing system in the prevailing economic conditions. Centralised wage fixing has become a disincentive for productivity and until businesses are given the opportunity to negotiate fair wage systems with their employees on an individual basis the situation will not get any better. We have had terrific examples of the failure of the wage fixing system over recent weeks. One such example is the number of innovative small businesses which have emerged to enter the recycling area. In Lismore there is a very significant small business involved in the recycling of paper, plastic and glass. The centralised wage fixing system had forced that business to the edge of bankruptcy. Jobs were on the line. The owner had only one way to turn. So with the consent of his employees he converted them to subcontractors. He restored incentive to the workplace. As a result, productivity has improved threefold while the wages of his former employees, who are now his subcontractors, have doubled. That is not a figment of my imagination. If Senator Burns would like to look at the press release where this information appears I will show it to him.

There is definitely an urgent need for voluntary employment agreements which would be enforceable under common law and would not be subject to the rorts and the unenforceability that operate under this current wage system. Wages and conditions must closely parallel the needs and profitability of an enterprise. It has really been sad to see the handling by our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of the current airlines dispute. The `them and us' attitude referred to by Mr Hawke has been a thing of the past. He is a product of an outmoded industrial relations system which uses confrontation rather than consensus as the opening gambit to negotiation.

We have heard all week about the horrific effect this industrial relations system is having on small business, particularly the travel industry and resort leisure activities and facilities. Travel agents have lost thousands of dollars. It goes on and on. Only today one of the contracted hire car drivers who is used in the Senate car pool claimed that unless this matter is resolved within a month he and a number of others like him in Canberra will be bankrupt. We have already talked about bankruptcy. We know what happens when that occurs-we can get a video from Senator Bolkus which will tell us all about it. It is a deplorable situation.

It was said earlier, I think by Senator McLean, that the small business sector does not have political clout. But it does have the Australian Small Business Association. I would like to quote a couple of extracts from a press release issued by that Association's President last July-before the pilots strike, before the attack on the pharmacists, before the Budget, before the high interest rates:

Far from helping small business the government and government agencies use their monopoly power, tax concessions and taxpayers' subsidies to disadvantage small businesses in every part of Australia. All government agencies and government run instrumentalities are exempt from land rates, council rates, petrol tax, sales tax, fringe benefits tax and payroll tax.

The small business sector employs 60 per cent of the private work force and has the capacity to expand and cure the twin evils of unemployment and foreign debt. The Government should be giving small business every possible assistance, but sadly the Ministers are slow to act to correct inequities . . .
The important thing that the President of the Association said was:

The Australian Small Business Association does not call for any financial subsidy whatsoever for small business, but merely asks that government get off the back of small business and create a climate of incentive and reward for the small business proprietor who is prepared to work far longer hours than most people in the community.

I think that paragraph sums up the situation so far as small business is concerned. If small business were allowed to compete, to employ people without being interfered with by a government that seems to be interested only in the big operator, a government-as Senator Boswell said earlier-that is responsible only for turning big business into small business because of the economic situation, small business would certainly start to give benefits to the community.

In the final few seconds I have left I will refer to another matter that is coming forward: the privacy legislation. Mr Barron, the State Director of the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce, when speaking of the Privacy Amendment Bill, said:
In this State, the overwhelming majority of businesses are small . . .

He said that there is no doubt that some will fail if this legislation is passed. There will be a lot more debate over the next couple of weeks about the privacy legislation. I hope I have the opportunity to speak on it because this, in itself, is another attack on small business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to depart from what other honourable senators have been doing in this debate and talk about the matter of public importance-I hope I am excused for that. Before doing so, I would like to rebut some of the points raised about pharmacists. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal has been in operation for some years. Many of the decisions that it has made have been accepted by the pharmacists because they have been fairly beneficial. This Government does not lose sight of the importance of pharmacists. But the bottom line for us obviously is that they deliver a service at a reasonable cost to the ordinary people of this country. We are, however, conscious that in some areas there will be a need to assist pharmacies-for example, pharmacies in isolated areas which need that service.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell said that he would rather look at symptoms than causes in relation to small business problems. I can assure him that I would rather look at the causes. If we can eliminate them we will not have the symptoms. I think Senator Calvert mentioned centralised wage fixation. I can assure him, if he does not know, that this system sets only a minimum wage; it does not prevent any employer from paying additional wages. It does not in any way restrict any employee from doing his best and creating the highest level of productivity. Even Justice Higgins in 1907 made the point that if an employer had a horse that he used in his business, he would make sure it was well fed and healthy so that it could do its job. A worker, his wife and three children should be treated no less. If an employer cannot pay the desired wage levels, he should get out of business and allow those who are efficient to do so.

Any government that does not realise the importance of small business is very stupid. That tag cannot be applied to this Government. The problem is that many people often go into small business badly equipped and ill-prepared. They have heaps of enthusiasm and some knowledge but they cannot translate that into a successful business. They have problems of inadequate finances and lack of adequate knowledge of business practices. These deficiencies are endemic. Problems that many of them bring to their new endeavours include lack of adequate finance, inadequate knowledge of bookkeeping and difficulties with debtors. Recognising these problems, the Federal Government has given considerable assistance to small business. Ninety-five per cent of agricultural businesses are small businesses and they employ 44 per cent of the private sector work force.

During 1986 to 1987 there was a 15 per cent increase in the number of enterprises. This hardly amounts to a dramatic downturn in business. The Australian Labor Party has always had a concern for the democratic process. People involved in manufacturing and small business of any kind should have a say about the future of their businesses. With this in mind, we set up the Small Business Council in 1984 to provide advice on small business issues.

In March 1988 the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) asked the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology to inquire into problems facing small business. That report, which is expected soon, will focus on issues of concern to all small businesses. What is the Committee inquiring into? Its terms of reference are: the unique problems faced by small business as a result of the extensive, yet fragmented, regulations under which they are governed and ways in which the administration of regulations can be improved-I refer here to the different State government, Federal government and local government laws; the impact of government policies in such areas as taxation, superannuation, training, marketing, access to information, advice and industrial relations; and the ultimate extent of policies on small businesses compared with larger businesses. The Committee has held hearings in all States and there has been considerable small business input. That is tremendously important. Small businesses have had an opportunity to say what they think. Their views can be considered and recommendations can be made to the Parliament. It is hoped that the report will provide a blueprint for the future.

Since 1986, the Commonwealth has provided $17m per annum to the States for programs. It decided to set up a body which is called the National Industries Extension Services (NIES). Before NIES was set up, private consultants were retained to focus on the problems and suggest solutions. We did not just say, `Let's set up the service and decide what to do later'. We had a look at what needed to be done. NIES is a joint Federal-State initiative. It provides the manufacturing industry with a central source of information and advice and it subsidises firms in the traded goods sector to receive specialist consulting advice. The Federal Government supplies the money and the States do most of the work, and very successfully, even though the States may have governments of different political persuasions. For example, management and marketing aspects are taken into consideration, as are productivity and design, plant layout, technology application, job design and employee participation-something that honourable senators on the other side of the House are not interested in. They are not concerned about industrial democracy whereby people are encouraged to be part of the decision-making process and therefore have a responsibility in terms of production and the quality of the goods that they produce.

NIES is not into rescuing companies but into making good companies better; that is, if a company is hopeless the market will find that out and the market will deal with it. Australian United Gems, which two years ago was a two-man company with a vision to export, now has the planning, marketing and manufacturing know-how to realise a $1m a year dream. This Queensland company had received a NIES maximum subsidy of $7,000 for business planning. That was a Federal Government initiative in conjunction with the State Government. Of course, we are concerned about small business. We are doing something in a concrete fashion to meet that need.

In Queensland more than 500 companies have been helped by NIES with business plans and manufacturing programs. A NIES work book kit has been produced. It is a very substantial instrument to help small business to be successful. There is a video and a business planner. There is a booklet entitled, `Your Business Now: A Self Diagnostic Work Book' which helps one to see where one is going wrong. The NIES work book kit allows one to focus on those sorts of things. These are real and important steps that the Government has been taking.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about bankruptcy?
—Senator Lewis talks about bankruptcy. One cannot prevent a hopeless business person who is keen to be a big business person from going broke if he overreaches himself and is greedy.

SPEECH.PARA: In February this year, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) released the NIES work book kit which was designed to help small business. It has sold more than 5,000 copies at a price of $55 per copy. Obviously, it is a useful tool and is much sought after by small business. The kit is designed to help companies which employ between 10 and 100 people and which have little opportunity to employ professional help. The comprehensive work book, video and business planner pose questions such as, `How strong is your industry position?', `How strong is your organisation?', `What is the enterprise strength of your organisation?', and also look at financial performance check lists and performance criteria. The kit is designed to focus on the key issues that determine success or failure. It emphasises the causes rather than the symptoms. If one removes the causes, there are no symptoms. Honourable senators opposite will have to tell Senator Boswell that. He is not here; he should have waited and listened. We could have educated him, like we are educating other honourable senators opposite.

In particular, the work book provides detailed information for small business to assess their profitability, gearing and finance, liquidity, efficiency and productivity. This is a real help for small business, rather than this raving by Opposition senators about economic circumstances and how the Government has not cared about business. I am talking specifically about the way in which the Government assists business, so that people in this country can understand, in a very basic and simple way, what we are doing. The Minister, Barry Jones, when announcing the release of a work book kit to assist small business, said:
Small businesses were vital to the nation's economic well being. Although the market was tough and uncompromising, it held great opportunities for growth and prosperity for well-managed firms.

Those are not the words of someone who does not care; those are the words of a man who cares about small business, who understands its importance to the community and who also understands the importance to the community of individuals in small business.

In terms of assistance provided in the Budget, much has been said about increased taxation revenue, but recently we reduced company tax from 49c to 39c in the dollar. That was a pretty substantial reduction. Another important aspect that is often missed is that the prices and incomes accord that was agreed to between the Australian Labor Party before it came to government and the unions provides for the acceptance of the redirection by companies of some wages into profits. That has been the case for nine to 10 years. Obviously, they must be used for the purpose of reinvestment, to provide more jobs. We are not in the business of saying, `We want you to have more profits so that you can go to Hawaii twice a month. We want you to reinvest, provide more jobs and thus increase the prosperity of more people in the community'. To some extent that has happened, but in some cases it has not. It shows the very conscious, positive and productive way in which the trade unions go about their work and the way in which this Labor Government has provided opportunities for business.

The Government has amended the wholesale tax law exempting equipment and materials for use in specified processes in the manufacture of goods. The threshold amount of average sales by a manufacturer above which goods will become taxable increased from $12,000 to $50,000. The threshold amount of sales tax liability above which goods become taxable increased from $250 to $1,000. All of these measures are meant to help small business, yet the Opposition has the hide to say that we do not care about small businesses. We care about them much more than does the Opposition.

The deregulation of financial markets, the removal of interest rate controls, was also accomplished by this Government. We also abolished State purchasing preferences, which allowed small businesses who had the capacity to compete from State to State to get interstate contracts. Previously, small businesses were only protected by their own State laws and therefore we did not have a situation where the most competent companies provided goods by way of tender. This Government has also continued support for the small business award program. That is only a small thing, but it is important. There was also the introduction of the `Buy Australian' program, and the publication of the Small Business Review, which is an informative source of data for small businesses. Austrade assists with the development of business strategy, taking into account emerging international market opportunities and intelligence. Before the Labor Party came into office, most of this applied to agricultural goods, not to manufactured goods. The current Government has altered that policy, and Austrade now assists tremendously with the marketing of manufactured goods overseas.

In competitive world marketing, the Commonwealth Government has taken certain initiatives. It has provided assistance to small business for research and development. Small business has received a 150 per cent tax break for this purpose. The management and investment companies program has encouraged the development of the venture capital market in Australia. It has provided financial support for Australian based overseas enterprises to invest in start-up early growth. Investors in these companies gain significant tax relief totalling 100 per cent. I refer also to Government purchasing policies, export incentives, export insurance and finance facilities, the Commonwealth Development Bank and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The vast majority of small innovative firms in emerging Australian industries are engaged in exporting to some degree. Many of these industries are highly export oriented. All of these measures are directed towards helping small business, by a conscientious government that really cares.

The Australian Taxation Office will introduce new information to assist small business. A major problem facing small business is how to tackle its tax affairs and the lack of information to do so. The Australian Taxation Office has identified small business as a priority area for information services in 1989-90. Following discussions with the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia it has more closely identified the information needs of small businesses and the best way in which it can meet those needs. The Australian Taxation Office has said to small businesses, `What are your problems? We will try to help you with them'. The Taxation Commissioner's advisory panel is to have an input from the Council of Small Business Organisations. `What do you want? How can we help you?' is the cry from the Labor Government. It is not, `We will tell you how to do it' but, `We will help. Tell us what your problems are'. There is the inclusion of a tax component in TAFE college courses. We are trying to change our culture so that when young people go through school they will understand what small business is about. They will not think one just puts up a sign, has $5,000, opens up a shop or business and has to be successful. Those are the things this Government is doing. I think they are important. The proposition put forward by the Opposition is totally dishonest and cannot be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate my coalition colleagues Senator Boswell and Senator Calvert on their important and significant contribution to this debate on small business this afternoon. At the same time, I would like to acknowledge that charitable gentleman from Victoria, Senator Barney Cooney, for his very generous comments on my private member's Bill being taken up as part of the Government's Budget. The tragedy for the Australian Labor Party (ALP) is that the real thinkers in the Labor Party, like Senator Barney Cooney, Mr John Langmore and others, are not on the front bench.

SPEECH.PARA: Almost 800,000 small business enterprises currently operate in Australia and employ almost 2,000,000 people. Almost 31 per cent of the Australian work force is employed in this small business sector. It is significant to note that small business accounts for 55 per cent of all private sector investment and 40 per cent of industry value added. The significance of this matter of importance today is that small business is under attack by this uncaring Federal Government. No longer does the ALP Government consult adequately with the relevant sectors before imposing changes, many of which are detrimental to the maintenance of a stable business environment which is so essential for small business. One finds that in taxation, retirement incomes policy, monetary policy with its high interest rates, government charges and regulations and micro-economic policy, small business is the forgotten sector.

Senator Burns, who has now left the chamber, was so proud of the high uptake of some of the Government booklets to help small business. I remind him that the uptake was less than one per cent. The Government's peak department in this area, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, provides no direction as its personnel are demoralised with the lack of leadership, high staff losses and the number of its activities being transferred to other Ministries, whose heads believe that they can do a better job. Earlier initiatives by the Minister are being scaled down, with small business being placed in a position of going it alone, despite the earlier high expectations. The rhetoric is still there, as Senator Burns will tell us, but the delivery is missing. No longer is government fulfilling its essential role of establishing and maintaining stable conditions within which all firms can compete on reasonably equal terms, particularly with government. If there is any monitoring of the effect of the Government's economic, fiscal and industry policies, and the impact of its leadership, the Government is certainly not responding to the signals that are there, or heeding the advice.

Small businesses and home owners are being singled out. They are being asked, unreasonably, to carry the full impact of the Government's single-minded resolution to adjust an overheated economy through excessive reliance on interest rate policy with its very damaging effects on small business and small home owners. No wonder bankruptcies are rising and running at record levels. In the same environment we find Government business enterprises continuing their spending sprees, with instrumentalities such as Telecom Australia anticipating spending over $300m on an office block in a central business district of Melbourne in Exhibition Street. We have other statutory organisations and departments on spending sprees with computers costing hundreds of millions of dollars. For example, the Taxation Office has spent $1,000m, and the Department of Defence has spent $400m on project DESINE. At the same time these spending sprees on computers add to the massive pressure on the government sector and add significant weight to our balance of payments difficulties. It is not surprising that there is so much bitterness coming from the business sector because of the treatment by this Federal Labor Government. Large foreign debt has ensured that the cost of capital needed to make business competitive is very much higher in this country than in other countries. The taxation regime has undermined incentive; the changing nature of government policy has created an air of uncertainty in the public mind, particularly from small business; and then there is the complexity of legislation, for example, the drawback scheme. Often we find the cost of producing the information required for a refund exceeds benefits which are able to be claimed. The system is geared to the large concerns producing simple products but not to small business.

May I contrast this position with that which is operating in Japan, where small businesses are encouraged; they facilitate and underpin the great flexibility and productive capacity of the great Japanese economy. In Japan small business has played, and is expected to continue to play, a pivotal role in that nation's economic success. It is not under attack, as it is in Australia, but is encouraged. Major Japanese industries extensively contract out work to an array of small, flexible and efficient family businesses. This Federal Government can assist small business by providing a stable economic environment which places greater reliance on market forces to facilitate economic growth and employment without undue government interference and intervention. Rules and regulations imposed on small businesses by the three tiers of government pose a threat to the efficient operation and growth of the small business sector. Small business is constantly frustrated by a myriad of rules and regulations which, to small business, appear to have no clear purpose or rationale. Small business feels that it has particular burdens in regulations relating to superannuation, the fringe benefits tax, pay as you earn tax, sales tax, child support, capital gains tax, Customs, tax audits, municipal taxes and numerous other rules and regulations.

I would like to point out that numerous Budget changes have had an impact on small business. Many small businesses are in a corporate form. Recently they have adjusted to the new method of quarterly instalments for meeting their company tax obligations. As a result of these Budget changes they now find themselves having to pay 85 per cent of their tax obligation within 15 days of the close of a financial year. The severity of this measure will have a major impact on the small business sector and on financial markets. Many small businesses just will not be in a position to raise overdraft facilities to find such a massive amount of money. My colleagues on the other side of the House seem oblivious to the fact that profit earned is not always simultaneous with cash received. In many cases the cash has to go out to pay the tax obligation before it is even received by the taxpayer under these conditions. They will have to be revised.

In conditions of declining profitability the rush to get accountants from outside the business to prepare the accounts within 15 days and pay the tax is an impossible situation. In other words, there are not enough accountants to meet the sort of demand that will be expected by this Government, which has lost touch with the small business community. The Government has just gone too far too quickly. It is not surprising that the wrath of the business community is gaining such a head of steam, the effects of which will be felt by this Government. Mr Bob Gottliebsen from the Business Review Weekly said that Canberra's pay as you earn politicians and public servants simply did not understand that business was run on cash flow rather than profits.

However, I must say that all is not gloom and doom. I acknowledge the Government's generosity in picking up my private member's Bill. This was something which was well overdue, something that should have been introduced when self-assessment was first introduced into the system. I am pleased that we now have a greater equality or neutrality between the Tax Office and taxpayers. It is only right that, in the provision of information to the Taxation Office, a taxpayer is able to secure professional advice and claim a deduction for it. On the other hand, the high cost of appeals through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has risen dramatically under this Government. It is now $300 per person involved. So for a small business with, say, three partners the cost would be $900. If that appeal is successful they do not get even one cent of the $900 back. So there is not much incentive to appeal.

Of concern also is the fact that where errors are made by the Taxation Office, for example where a computer operator keys in a wrong figure for prescribed payments tax and there is a delay in a refund to the taxpayer of perhaps four months, there is no obligation or even a requirement for interest to be paid by the Tax Office for the Tax Commissioner's mistake. But if a taxpayer or small business is late in paying tax, heavy penalties are involved. All too frequently press releases precede legislation, not by weeks, not by months, but by years. Having adjusted their businesses to the foreshadowed changes, small businesses frequently find themselves in a position where the subsequent legislation differs in major areas from the original announcement.

In the Budget announcement of 15 August we saw a retrospective application of capital gains tax. If it had not been for the early intervention of the Australian Taxpayers Association, the Government would have taken excessive amounts through additional issues of shares via the capital gains tax mechanisms. In the retirement incomes area, we find that stable businesses require a long term superannuation regime where amounts must be put aside for retirement.

In May 1988 the Treasurer promised that there would be no further changes to superannuation, that Australians now could plan with confidence and certainty. Yet the recently passed tax Bills create a myriad of uncertainty and complexity. They will raise an extra $1m from the savings of ordinary Australians and small businesses. The legislation is an administrative nightmare in terms of both complexity and retrospectivity. The real beneficiaries are the Government-by virtue of the extra money it can get-the actuaries, the accountants, and the large superannuation firms. The small people have been raped of their savings and of their independence. Superannuation for lower and middle income earners is now becoming a much less attractive investment proposition. No longer is superannuation the efficient, long term retirement vehicle which is so necessary to guarantee security for people in their retirement years. In the last three years there has been a 400 per cent increase in the volume of legislation and rules relating to superannuation. Previously, the bureaucracy was limited to the Australian Taxation Office. Now we have two major bureaucracies administering this area: the Tax Office and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

The Contractors Association Ltd is an important small business organisation which is concerned about the Commissioner of Taxation rewriting the rule book. It is concerned that these reassessments are being issued not because of any dishonesty or non-disclosure by the taxpayer, but simply because of new interpretations of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It says that taxpayers have structured their affairs on the best professional advice only to find that the Commissioner for Taxation has rewritten the rule book. It says, `As small business people, we cannot live in a regime of retrospective reassessments'. Currently, many casual workers are disadvantaged by the tax system, particularly those who work for a second employer. This affects many small businesses which require daily casual labour. Section 221d of the tax file number provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act is not helping these people get jobs. If the Government were really concerned about helping low income earners it could devise a daily tax scale for those people similar to what has been achieved on a weekly basis for shearers. Small business is constantly calling for a simplification of the present 2,000 pages of complex, unclear rules. It has had to cope with capital gains tax, changes to negative gearing, substantiation prescribed payments and so on. There is a need for a greater re-examination of tax returns at the time of lodgment and the calculations of taxpayers. I am not advocating a lessening of the tax or the field audits but honest mistakes and misunderstandings of the Act are not being referred by the Australian Taxation Office to the Commissioner of Taxation quickly enough. Sometimes it takes three or five years and the penalties under such circumstances are quite horrific.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I was formerly in small business-it seems like an awfully long time ago; almost like another incarnation-so I have some sympathy with that sector. I acknowledge the important contribution of small business not only in those well-acknowledged areas of employment and the value that it adds to products but also because, in a sense, it is the wealth distributor. It is through the small business sector that wealth is conveyed to the people of this country. I acknowledge also the importance of keeping the small business sector strong and healthy. I believe that this Government, not only in its rhetoric but also through its actions, has acknowledged that importance.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sector fraught with problems but the problems are not unique to this Government, nor are they unique to this country; the problems are found worldwide and they cross political boundaries. Senator Watson talked about Japan as a shining example of how things should be done, but he failed to mention, because it did not suit his argument, that bankruptcies are rife in Japan and are probably comparable-I cannot give figures now because I did not come prepared for that-to those in Australia, as they are in Margaret Thatcher's England and as they are in Bush's United States of America. As these problems are a worldwide thing across political styles they cannot be uniquely sheeted home to the Australian Labor Party and this Government. So there is no point in quoting statistics and saying, `My bankruptcy rate is better than your bankruptcy rate', or that sort of thing.

The failure rate of small business is, I admit, a depressing problem. Let us look at the most comprehensive study at hand-the Williams longitudinal study entitled The Characteristics and Performance of Small Business in Australia 1973-85. That publication shows that of start-up businesses examined between 1973 and 1985, within three years 40 per cent failed and within five years 60 per cent failed. I draw attention to the fact that the period of the study spans the Fraser and Hawke governments. Eighty per cent of businesses failed because of a lack of management expertise, yet there is a marked reluctance to seek or use external help. Again that is something that is evident across the board and throughout the world; it is part of a small business syndrome, if you like. Only 6 per cent of businesses consulted advisers regularly in that period and 63 per cent never consulted external advisers.

It needs to be stressed again that this problem is not unique to this Government; it is worldwide and across styles of government. It is a problem in the nature of small business. The fact is that there is no shortage of Australians-and this is a sad fact-willing to gamble all on the prospect of running their own business. They are prepared to give it a go without much information and without any outside consultation; so they fail. It is also a fact that the Government's role in any direct sense will always be limited. In our system it is a shared role with the States. In essence, the Federal Government's role is twofold: the provision of economic conditions and a business infrastructure which is conducive to sustained growth and to the development of small firms-in the Federal Government's case it will also be interested particularly in export oriented firms-and, secondly, the provision of more direct assistance and exhortation with the assistance of the States and institutions such as banks, education institutions, professional groups, et cetera.

I think the Government's achievements in both of these areas have been remarkable. In the short time available to me I do not have time to go into them but some other speakers have already alluded to some of them. But I would like to draw attention to one area in which government, outside all the direct influences, has assisted quite a bit-that is, in exhorting institutions such as banks to take note--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.45 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it is not a popular thing to do at this hour of a Friday afternoon when people are desperately trying to get home by whatever means of transport they can, but I want to raise a matter of great moment because, as I understand it, a decision on this matter is likely to be made on Monday, presumably before the Senate meets again. I refer to the question of the status of Sheikh Mohammad Al Hilaly, the imam of the Lakemba Mosque in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: I have raised this matter in the past. It is a matter of major concern. The imam has been a resident of Australia with either a temporary permit or no permit whatsoever for something like seven years. Four years ago he was required to leave Australia because his permit to stay had expired. He failed to keep a commitment to leave, as required by the Government of the day. Yet now seven years later he is still without a permit to exist here, although an additional temporary one was given to him just a couple of months ago in a manner which involved misleading the Senate-I will raise that matter later-in order to allow him to go to Mecca. I have no concern on religious or other grounds. My concerns relate to whether or not the imam is a fit and proper person to be a permanent resident of this country.

I am very concerned that specific and special arrangements appear to have been made for the imam which are not made and never have been made to my knowledge for people, for example, from the city of Wollongong, where I have my office. There is an enormous migrant community in Wollongong where this kind of special concession would be unheard of. There have been continuing extensions of his permit to reside in Australia temporarily covering a period of seven years. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has still not made a determination about his status. I have before me the Department's draft submission to the Minister about whether or not the Minister should grant permanent residence to the imam. The reason I am raising this matter here is that a report on this application for resident status was to be forwarded to the Minister on 28 August 1989. That is long after any temporary permits would have expired and where normally someone would have been on their way out of the country by either being deported or under their own steam.

The imam was provided with an opportunity to make any comments in the letter dated 21 August by Thursday 24 August 1989. In other words, one assumes that the Minister has now received the detailed report and a decision is apparently about to be made at last. My concerns relate to some of the material in the draft submission to the Minister which strikes me as extraordinary. It is asserted in this recommendation that most allegations against Imam Hilaly are not supported by factual evidence and cannot be relied upon. It is not possible to determine on evidence whether they are true or not. The Jewish community in Sydney, for example, would be appalled that such a statement could be made.

It is incredible to me that an official document-and, as I understand it, this is the draft of the recommendation of the Minister-could make such an assertion. If there are people who can provide factual evidence-and I am assured that there are-I would hope that they would make certain that that factual evidence is presented to this Minister before he acts on this grossly inadequate departmental report. It goes on:
There is evidence indicating that the Imam Hilaly's presence in Australia has the support of the Government of Libya or its agents.
This is a very serious matter indeed. The report goes on:

That Government has contributed not insubstantial sums to support the organizations which fund, inter alia, the Imam's expenses. Such expenses include the legal expenses for the Federal Court appeal against the Government's decision in 1986 not to grant Imam Hilaly permanent residence and for the Commonwealth's (successful) appeal to the Full Federal Court.

As I say, it seems to me to be particularly serious when, as the report says, `There is evidence indicating that the Imam Hilaly's presence in Australia has the support of the Government of Libya or its agents'. The report goes on to say that, in responding to questions on this, Imam Hilaly indicated, `I also personally did not receive one cent out of this amount' and `I have not received any money and this report . . . is incorrect'-that was a contemporary media account. The report goes on:

Literally and physically, it is accepted that the Imam did not receive one cent from the grant from an agency supported by the Libyan Government. However, it is open to hold that the Imam did benefit from those funds which entered a pool of funds from which monies are paid, inter alia, for the Imam's purposes.
It seems to be to be quite a misleading statement by the Imam. The report goes on:

There is no evidence that the amount in question was directed specifically to meet the Imam's expenses. Moreover, there is no evidence that the grant of such monies to the Australian Federation of Islamic Councils was in consideration for general or specific responses to be made by that Federation or others in Australia. To the contrary, Imam Hilaly said, `We cooperate with those overseas Islamic organisations for the benefit of Moslems but we will not be tied to their political government or political system and we accept assistance without conditions'.
I thought it proper to put the other side of this case so that I could not be held to be making a one-sided statement. The report goes on:

Further, the Imam indicated that he was unaware of the grant ``until the press announced this.'' In responding to a question as to why the Imam did not refute contrary views in ``The Australian'' of 16 December 1987, The Imam indicated, ``Today''-
that is, 16 August 1989-
``this is the first time I've become aware that The Australian newspaper have written something like this about me.''
Quite frankly, I find that very difficult to accept. The report goes on:

In pursuing the general theme, the Imam said that he visited Libya for an international conference some two years ago. According to Departmental records, this visit was between June and September 1987 when Imam Hilaly travelled out of Australia. The fare for this visit was also provided by an agency supported by the Libyan Government.
The report continues:

The Libyan Government-and its agents-has or have a reputation for actively and sometimes violently interfering in the affairs of foreign nations. Especially in matters concerning Israel and Lebanon, it has been seen by some as being aligned with the approach of governments which hold extreme views on international politics. It has as its president a person who is seen as the leader of the Revolution and who has been the ruler of Libya since before 1970. There have been suggestions that the Libyan Government or its agents have had an interest in extending its/their influence in areas of tension as remote from Libya as the Caribbean and the Pacific. Your views-
that is, the Minister's views-
on this matter and the relevance of it to Australia might or might not be relevant to the consideration of the Imam's application in light of all the evidence.
It is the next bit which really concerns me. It says:
It is noteworthy, however, that the relevant Australian Government agency has, on the information then available to it-
I do not know what `then' means-
indicated no objection to the Imam's continued presence in Australia.
The report states:
If you-
that is, the Minister-
do not agree with that view, you would be expected to have a reasonable basis for differing with that view.

I find it incredible that any security organisation in Australia would take the view that there is no matter for concern and no objection to the imam on the basis of these links with Libya. It seems to me, from that choice of words, that the Department is encouraging the Minister to take the view that the imam is on that basis someone who is acceptable to become a permanent resident of Australia. The key point to remember is that the imam's behaviour, which has been so divisive over the past seven years and particularly over recent years, has been despite the admonition of the Australian Government that he should behave and despite his assurance that he would behave, having created such turmoil and distress among so many people who have been offended and upset by his intemperate comments. What would be the likely pattern of behaviour of this man once those constraints which have acted so ineffectively against him were removed? That question is not raised in the Department's submission to the Minister. The report to the Minister continues:

You might hold that answers to questions put to Imam Hilaly on this most sensitive question do not allay reasonably held concerns about the Imam's links with Libya which, to our knowledge, commenced in 1973. Certainly the answers speak of receiving grants without attached conditions, and the Imam says, `From my earlier days in Libya I have taken the stand that is in opposition to Libya . . .'.-
I must say that that seems unlikely-
But the Imam's answers also contain apparent inconsistencies about his actions in the matter.

Even though some allegations made against Imam Hilaly are not supported by evidence, it is undeniable that there are divisions within the Lebanese community in Sydney, evidenced by the fact that strong allegations are made against Imam Hilaly and equally strongly denied by his supporters. Imam Hilaly's presence appears to arouse deep-seated passions within the community among both his supporters and opponents.

I stress, without any special pleading for the Jewish community, that the report recognises that Imam Hilaly has not publicly retracted or apologised for his remarks of September 1988 which were massively divisive and grievously offensive to the Jewish community in Australia. The Executive Council of Australian Jewry wrote to the Minister expressing unequivocal opposition to Imam Hilaly being allowed to remain in Australia. That Council believes that Imam Hilaly represents a direct threat to the Jewish community here and presents a real danger of inciting anti-Semitic acts, including violent acts, against Jewish people and institutions in Australia. After recognition of that submission by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry, it is intriguing that the report to the Minister states:
It is difficult to know, amid all the claims and counter claims in this case just where the real truth lies.

If the Department cannot tell where the real truth lies on the evidence that abounds, I hope that its level of performance can increase substantially in a qualitative sense. Having read the recommendation, it appears to be paving the way for an acceptance by the Minister of the suggestion that perhaps the imam should be allowed to stay which would involve a breaking of almost every one of the accepted standards of a multicultural society on which there is bipartisan support in Australian politics.

I simply say once again that I raised this matter because of my extreme concern that what strikes me as a misleading and inadequate recommendation to the Minister may be acted on in the very near future. I can only hope that the Minister, whom I personally regard very highly for both his integrity and his capacity, will be able to see from the very brief remarks I have made here today that his actions in this area should not be encouraged by this report by his Department to allow Sheikh Al Hilaly the Imam of the Lakemba Mosque, to become a permanent resident of Australia, because I believe that he would be an even more divisive element in the future than he has been in the past.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
